PARA.TAB: (1) A Bargaining Division of the Commission is established.
(2) The Division consists of the Vice President, and the other member or members of the Commission assigned to it under section 170NK.

TAB.TAB: 170NJ Role of the Bargaining Division

PARA.TAB: (1) Subject to this Part, the Bargaining Division is to perform and exercise:

TAB.TAB: (a) the Commission's functions and powers under this Part; and
(b) the Commission's functions and powers in relation to an industrial dispute in relation to which a bargaining period has been initiated under section 170MI.

PARA.TAB: These are called the Bargaining Division's function and powers.
(2) The Bargaining Division's functions and powers may only be performed and exercised:

TAB.TAB: (a) by a member of the Division; or
(b) by a member of the Commission in accordance with a declaration in force under subsection 170NL(1); or
(c) by the Commission constituted by 2 or more of its members, each of whom is:
(i) a member of the Division; or
(ii) a member of the Commission acting in accordance with a declaration in force under subsection 170NL(1); or
(d) by a Full Bench (whether on appeal or otherwise); or
(e) by the President under section 108.

PARA.TAB: (3) Subsection (2) does not affect the validity of any act or decision.

TAB.EMPHASIS: 170NK Assignment of Commission members to the Bargaining Division

PARA.TAB: (1) The Governor‐General may by writing assign to the Bargaining Division a Vice President or acting Vice President, unless a Vice President or acting Vice President is already assigned to the Division.
(2) The Governor‐General may by writing assign to the Division a member of the Commission (except the President, a Vice President or an acting Vice President).
(3) In this section, "acting Vice President" means a person acting in an office of Vice President during a vacancy in the office.

EMPHASIS.TAB: 170NL Exercise of Bargaining Division's functions and powers by other Commission members

PARA.TAB: (1) The President may make available a member of the Commission to perform or exercise all or any of the Bargaining Division's functions and powers, as the President thinks fit.

(2) The President may, under subsection (1), make a member of the Commission available to perform or exercise functions and powers of the Bargaining Division either generally or as the President otherwise specifies.
(3) The President must exercise the power under subsection (1) by written declaration.

TAB.EMPHASIS: 170NM Composition of Full Bench established to perform or exercise any of the Bargaining Division's functions and powers

PARA.TAB: (1) A Full Bench established for the purposes of a proceeding that will involve performing or exercising any of the Bargaining Division's functions and powers (whether on appeal or otherwise) must consist, so far as practicable, of members of the Bargaining Division.
(2) Before establishing a Full Bench for the purposes of such a proceeding, the President must consult the Vice President assigned to the Bargaining Division.

TAB.EMPHASIS: 170NO Organisation of the Bargaining Division's work

PARA.TAB: The Vice President assigned to the Bargaining Division is to organise and allocate its work.

The other member or members of the Division, and a member or members made available to the Division under subsection 170NL(1), must comply with the Vice President's directions in relation to that work.

TAB.EMPHASIS: 170NP Assignment of other work to Bargaining Division

PARA.TAB: (1) A member of the Bargaining Division may, as well as performing and exercising the Bargaining Division's functions and powers, perform other functions, and exercise other powers, as a member of the Commission, but only as provided by Part VIC or in accordance with a determination under subsection (2).

(2) The President may determine in writing that specified members of the Bargaining Division are to perform specified functions, and exercise specified powers, as members of the Commission, either generally or as otherwise specified in the determination.
(3) Before making an instrument under subsection (2), the President must consult the Vice President assigned to the Bargaining Division.
(4) A determination under subsection (2) has effect despite section 37, in so far as the determination relates to a member of the Commission who is not a member of the relevant panel.
(5) Subsection (1) does not affect the validity of an act or decision.

(2) The AWA, or the AWA in combination with any awards that are applicable, must not, in relation to the terms and conditions of employment of the employee subject to the AWA, disadvantage the employee.
(3) For the purposes of subsection (2), an agreement is taken to disadvantage an employee in relation to his or her terms and conditions of employment only if:

TAB.TAB: (a) approval of the agreement would result in the reduction of any entitlement or protections of the employee under:
(i) an award (as defined in subsection (4)); or
(ii) any other law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory that the Commission thinks relevant; and
(b) in the context of the terms and conditions of employment considered as a whole, the Commission considers that the reduction is contrary to the public interest.

PARA.TAB: (4) In this section "award" includes:

TAB.TAB: (a) a State award;
(b) an award which the Commission determines is appropriate for establishing the entitlements and protections of the employee for the purposes of subsection (3); and
(c) an AWA;

PARA.TAB: but does not include an order under Part VIA.
(5) The Commission must be satisfied that the employee whose employment will be subject to the AWA has genuinely made the AWA.
(6) The AWA must include procedures for preventing and settling disputes between the employer and the employee whose employment will be subject to the agreement about matters arising under the AWA.
(7) The AWA must specify a date as the nominal expiry date of the AWA, and that date cannot be more than 3 years after the day on which the AWA will come into operation.
(8) Despite subsections (2), (3), (4) and (5), the Commission must refuse to approve an AWA if it is satisfied that:

TAB.TAB: (a) the employer has, in connection with negotiating the AWA, contravened Division 1A; or

(b) the employer has caused a person or body to engage, in connection with negotiations for the AWA, in conduct that, had the employer engaged in the conduct, would be a contravention by the employer of Division 1A; or
(c) a person or body has, on behalf of the employer:
(i) so engaged in such conduct; or
(ii) caused another person or body so to engage in such conduct.

PARA.TAB: (9) Despite subsections (2), (3), (4) and (5), the Commission must refuse to approve an AWA if it thinks that a provision of the AWA discriminates against the employee whose employment will be subject to the AWA because of, or for reasons including, race, colour, sex, sexual preference, age, physical or mental disability, marital status, family responsibilities, pregnancy, religion, political opinion, national extraction, social origin or membership of an organisation of employees.
(10) For the purpose of subsection (9), a provision of an agreement does not discriminate against an employee merely because:

TAB.TAB: (a) before 22 June 1997, it provides for a junior rate of pay; or
(b) it discriminates, in respect of particular employment, on the basis of the inherent requirements of that employment; or
(c) it discriminates, in respect of employment as a member of the staff of an institution that is conducted in accordance with the teachings or beliefs of a particular religion or creed:
(i) on the basis of those teachings or beliefs; and
(ii) in good faith.

Motion (by Mr Reith) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay, Leo, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very nice to have an audience here for the adjournment debate tonight. Mr Deputy Speaker, for one short moment they were all entranced. I would like to raise the question of the ongoing problems in the Republic of Cyprus, which are of great interest to the Cypriot and Greek communities in Australia, and indeed the broader Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: The Cypriot community in Australia have taken part this week in the proceedings of Refugee Week here in Canberra. Refugee Week was brought to the attention of the House earlier on in the week by the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock), and, unfortunately, other than that passing remark of the minister, the government did not seem to say much more on the matter.

I think that we should pause towards the end of Refugee Week and consider the plight of people in Australia who are refugees from strife and turmoil in their own land. In particular, I think we should pay some attention to the plight of refugees in Australia from the Republic of Cyprus, particularly those people from the northern part of that country that has been occupied by the Turkish army for the last 22 years.

Our hearts should go out to the people from the Kyrenia district of Cyprus, in particular. A large number of families in this country who came from that part of Cyprus were expelled by the Turks in the 1970s when the Turkish invaders invaded northern Cyprus. They have seen their property handed over to Turkish settlers.

Many of these Australian citizens have been particularly disadvantaged just because their names are Greek. When the Turkish army invaded northern Cyprus, the Turks originally went round and said to people who were foreign nationals that they should hang the flag of their country outside their homes and they would not face expropriation of their property.

There were many British nationals, Americans and people from other parts of Europe who had property in Cyprus. They still own those properties in northern Cyprus. The people who lost their properties were people with Greek names. Many of those people lived in Australia; they were not living in Cyprus at the time of the invasion. For example, there is an Irish woman who is the widow of a Greek Cypriot. She is an Australian citizen and holds proper title to a property in northern Cyprus. But because her married name is Greek, the Turkish occupying power will not recognise her title to this property.

I think that the Australian government should give assistance to these Australian citizens who own property in northern Cyprus to run a case in the International Court of Justice to re‐acquire their property. Earlier tonight we heard a lot from the government about the rights of individuals in property and to property. Surely the Australian government should do something to help these Australian citizens re‐acquire the property that was stolen from them by force of arms. They were discriminated against just because of their names. If you were a Greek Cypriot whose mother might have been a Greek Cypriot and whose father was British and had an Anglo-Saxon name, your property was not confiscated. The only property that was lost was property that was owned by people with Greek names. I think that is a scandal. I commend that legal action to the House. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish, of necessity, to make some edited comments about the issue of euthanasia, given that the Northern Territory (Rights of the Terminally Ill) Bill is about to take effect. I was addressing a conference two years ago and an elderly man interjected from the back of the audience. He said, `This is all very well, but what are you doing about the issue of euthanasia? The old people of Australia don't know how they are going to survive without it.' This reflects the degree of understanding that some people have.

BREAK.PARA: With the passage of the Northern Territory (Rights of the Terminally Ill) Bill, Australia is about to change irrevocably. Those who think that the legislation and its effect and impact will be confined to the borders of the Northern Territory, I think, are sadly misguided. We have moved, over the last 10 years in particular, into what I call an era of legislative morality, where we think as a nation that all of the problems we have, whether of racial vilification or the care of dying people, can be solved by going to statutes and passing laws.

There are many who think that this kind of legislation ought to be supported, because around 80 per cent of people responding to polls support it. The reality of that is that just because something is popular does not make it right. When people are going down the supermarket aisle on a Saturday morning looking for cornflakes and somebody says, `I'm from Newspoll. Do you think the law ought to be changed to allow doctors to end the suffering of people who are dying?', I am surprised that not 100 per cent of the people surveyed say yes.

Much of the apparent support in the community for euthanasia legislation is driven by ignorance and fear. It is driven by a fear of dying an unnecessarily painful and undignified death. Whilst we are all obviously going to die, for most people death is a largely hypothetical experience. They have not seen a dead body. They have not sat through a death day after day, night after night and seen what it is all about.

No matter what we provide—with all the wonders of modern medicine and all the support of palliative care—in about two per cent of cases not all human pain and suffering can be relieved and, of course, not all of it is physical. But those who argue that changing the law, that sanctioning the intentional ending of human life, is going to relieve all pain and suffering are sadly misguided. The law is a very blunt instrument, and I believe it does not have the finesse to deal with all of those areas of human endeavour.

I have cared for many people who have died—I hope that is not a reflection on my medical skills—and I also had my own brother die last year after a long illness. I chaired the AMA's Ethics and Professional Conduct Committee for three years, and I have dealt with a lot of complaints about doctors. I assure you that I would like to think I come at this issue from a position of commonsense.

The concepts of trust and respect are more likely to flourish in a relationship which is governed by ethics, morality and commonsense. Every death, like every birth, is different to the one that came before it and the one that comes after it. Those who think that generalisations or even a set of principles or a code of ethics are going to cover all the situations in which we inevitably find ourselves, either as patients or as doctors, I think, are misguided.

The laws which cover the everyday transactions of life are quite difficult to introduce into a relationship between a doctor and a dying person and his or her family. It introduces a circumstance in which the doctor and the patient see each other as a potential adversary. Inevitably, under those circumstances, the interests of the patient suffer.

People when they are dying, understandably, are depressed. Not infrequently, people may have a wrong diagnosis. We have all met someone who was told three years ago that they had three months to live. In many cases, people are not being given access to modern methods for relieving pain and their suffering. My experience has been that those who cite cases, which apparently are arguments in favour of such legislation, fail to recognise that when doctors fail it is more often as human beings than as scientists.

Equally, I think the federal parliament simply cannot ignore the fact that one part of this country is about to change our values and that, on average, there is one youth suicide a day. Therefore, we cannot afford to legitimise death as a solution to what we think are insurmountable problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tanner, Lindsay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As I had a role in starting the argument, I want to make some observations on the debate that has been entered into by the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Southcott) and the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) with respect to the United Australia Party and its attitude to fascist regimes in Europe in the 1930s. There is ample evidence to demonstrate that, as in the United Kingdom, there was considerable sympathy within the United Australia Party, including from Sir Robert Menzies, for Hitler and Mussolini. It is important to distinguish their attitudes to those regimes and how those regimes conducted their affairs within their own countries from attitudes to appeasement and re‐armament, which are a distinct issue.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite true to say that the ALP in the mid-1930s was quite isolationist, but it did change later in the period. Of course, it was the Lyons government which recognised the Italian conquest. As with the United Kingdom conservatives, there were different views across all political parties about the issues of appeasement and how fascist aggression should be dealt with. The issue is not how Menzies and his cohorts responded to fascist threats to other countries; the issue is what their views were about what those fascist regimes were doing within their own countries.

The member for Boothby referred to a book by E.M. Andrews called Isolationism and appeasement in Australia. Of course, as the honourable member for Werriwa indicated, there are substantial references in that book which demonstrate quite conclusively that Menzies and his supporters were quite pro‐fascist in various ways; quite sympathetic. After Menzies' study tour in 1938, he talked of the `spiritual quality' of the Hitler Youth. He talked of Germany being `better governed under its dictatorship'. His Foreign Minister in his first government, Henry Gullett, talked of Mussolini's `genius, his patriotism and almost superhuman capacity' and Hitler's `shining record of service to his people'. Andrews concluded, after noting Menzies' reservations, I hasten to add, about the Nazi regime—and I quote:
He also felt—
this is Menzies—

that he had to see the good points in the Nazi regime: its very order and discipline were bound to appeal to the legal mind; its reputed opposition to all on the left appealed to his own sentiments. He thus fell into the trap of defending it.
So much for the protestations of the honourable member for Boothby. His own source says that Menzies was pro‐fascist, that Menzies was sympathetic to fascist regimes.

There is other evidence available. In 1938 Menzies told a gathering of Scotch College students that, although Hitler and Mussolini had in some respects gone too far, he had some admiration for what they were doing. In practical actions, this can also be seen. In l940, only a matter of days before Italy entered the war on the side of Germany, the Giornale Italiano, effectively an official publication from Italy, was being openly published and allowed to be published in Australia by the United Australia Party government, full of pro‐German propaganda. At the same time—and before then, of course—journals of the left had been suppressed and people in the left had been hounded, yet this journal of fascist propaganda, from a country which was about to go to war against the allies and was strongly supportive, prior to going to war against the allies, of the German cause, was allowed to continue publication by the then federal United Australia Party government until virtually the day that Italy entered the war.

The member for Boothby has used gross hyperbole and caricaturing of the member for Werriwa's argument to try to discredit it. He suggests that the member for Werriwa is arguing that Menzies was—and I quote from the speech by the member for Boothby the other night—`a closet Nazi' and `Australia's Kurt Waldheim'; `a dark, secret Nazi past' on the part of Menzies.

All of this is nonsense. The honourable member for Werriwa and I are not suggesting anything of the sort. We are arguing that the United Australia Party, the predecessors to today's Liberals, and Menzies, were relatively sympathetic to fascism at the time. They might have had some different views about the expansionist and aggressive intentions of the Nazi and Italian fascist regimes. But they were quite supportive in many respects of what those regimes were doing in their own societies.

To suggest, as the honourable member for Boothby did, that Menzies was a great democrat is laughable. Menzies was the man who tried to have a referendum passed so that he would be able to accuse people of being communists, throw them in gaol and then the onus would be on them to prove that they were not communists. The first public list that was issued contained several mistakes—people who were not members of the Communist Party. Yes, there were some people in the 1930s in the ALP who were sympathetic to fascism, Franco and Mussolini, but not to Hitler. But where did they end up? They ended up in the DLP. What did the DLP do? They kept the Liberal Party in power for 23 years federally. So the people in the Labor Party who were sympathetic to those fascist regimes ended up in their right political place eventually, that is, supporting the Liberal Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McDougall, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Filling in forms is one of the most tedious, time consuming and often apparently pointless exercises in our lives. This fact has been acknowledged by the creation of the Small Business Task Force, which is committed to eliminating 50 per cent of paperwork carried out by the business community.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest that we look at another area of serious form filling which affects almost everyone in our society—opening a bank account. I realise the Taxation Office will cringe in horror at the thought of going back to the days when one only had to walk into a bank with a dollar in hand and open an account to deposit that said dollar. This simple matter is burdened by the need to produce enough personal identification to meet a score of 100 points. What this means, for those with felonious intent, is a few hours at a computer loaded with a desktop publishing program. But what it means for the great majority of our citizens is the tiresome business of collecting documentation—enough to prove who you are several times over.

BREAK.PARA: For those fortunate enough to have a current passport, opening a bank account is made easier, as a passport qualifies for 70 points. Coupled with a drivers licence, worth 40 points, the tally is met and one can now deposit one's cash. But not everyone has a passport. Neither does everyone have a drivers licence. For these people the paper chase is quite extraordinary. The best they can get for the compulsory Medicare card is a mere 25 points in this, the quest for the vital 100 points.

A birth certificate, the original, is the next best option. But even with this, it is not a quick task, as those who have gone down this trail to get their passport renewed can testify. A letter and a cheque have to be sent to the relevant office of births, deaths and marriages, and then there is a wait for the original or a copy of the original birth certificate to arrive.

A young person just out of school, with little or no documentation, has a hard time finding these adult ID documents. If still at school, life is a little easier for a young person keen enough to open a savings account. An official letter from the school scores at least 40 points on this banking ID scale. Add to this the Medicare card—a mere 25 points—and they are halfway legal.

Our economists tell us this country urgently needs to improve its savings levels. I am not surprised they are so slow when establishing a bank account is such a tedious business. If fulfilling the point criteria meant a person opening a bank account automatically had access to all facilities, it could make a little more sense, but, of course, it does not. To get into the serious matter of borrowing the bank, naturally, does serious checking on the identification and collateral of its customer. So why the caution in the mere fact of opening the account?

The current system of demanding reams of documented proof of existence does not deter those who wish to open a second account in a different name to confuse authorities. I am not suggesting that we do not have a form of identification to appease the taxation department. What I am saying is that the current system is an overkill. I am sure banking staff as well as the millions of customers subjected to this procedure would be overjoyed if the system were less rigid. As well it would encourage more to start saving. It is ironic that no-one in this country—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 June, I brought to the attention of the House the plight of my constituent Leah Boyd who is suffering from the after‐ effects of a breast implant and the difficulties and agony that she and her husband were going through—particularly Leah, and the considerable ill health that she is enduring. I want to turn to an article in the Australian of 17 February 1996 in which Janet Fife‐Yeomans states:

SPEECH.PARA: Three out of four Australian women who have had silicon breast implants have had them removed. . .
Over 50,000 Australian have had breast implants and more than 4000 have ongoing legal claims against manufacturers.

Tonight I want to enlarge upon my comments of 18 June to compare this situation with what is happening in America. In the United States, a global settlement fund for breast implant recipients was established—I understand in 1994—for US women injured as a result of breast implants, with 97 per cent of the proceeds of that fund going to US women and three per cent to foreign women.

The discriminatory treatment was the subject of appeal, but that became irrelevant because the settlement fund collapsed due to a lack of funding. Following the collapse of the global settlement fund, the major non-Dow implant manufacturers announced a revised settlement for domestic claimants only. Only women with American citizenship or residency or women who had their implants inserted in the USA are eligible to participate.

The Dow Corning Corporation, the largest manufacturer of breast implants, has filed for chapter 11 bankruptcy in the Michigan Bankruptcy Court. A chapter 11 bankruptcy is non-liquidation—Dow Corning is not insolvent. It is probably similar to an Australian scheme of arrangement. The process allows the company to close off previous debts and liabilities for previous lawsuits and to emerge effectively as a new company. In a way, it is an escape from creditors.

As part of the chapter 11 process, all litigation against the company in the US has been stayed. When a company files for a chapter 11 bankruptcy under US law, it is required to present a company reorganisation plan to pay off previous debts. This includes product liability claims made against the company for personal injuries.

Some kind of settlement scheme must be proposed. This must be approved as fair by the judge in charge of the bankruptcy or the company reorganisation will not be approved. Judge Spector, the judge of the Michigan Bankruptcy Court overseeing the Dow Corning bankruptcy, has indicated that the discrimination against foreign women that occurred in the now defunct global settlement fund will not extend into bankruptcy proceedings.

Unfortunately, little progress appears to have been made in establishing a settlement fund for the 4,000 Australian women who have been injured by implants. The tragic aspect to all of this is that in the minds of some people there is a belief or an opinion that these women are simply chasing after money. They do not seem to recognise the intense agony and the loss of life that is occurring amongst so many of them.

The manufacturers do have a responsibility and that responsibility should be shared equally to Australian women. They should not be discriminated against in favour of American women. The reality is that no amount of money can replace the health of these women. No amount of money can bring back to children and the rest of the family the mother, the wife, as she was prior to the onset of that illness that resulted from the implant.

These women have not had the right to make a truly informed decision about their own bodies and lives because, as is claimed in those suits, there was not proper product information made available at the time of the decision to seek that implant or to have the procedure carried out.

BREAK.PARA: It is likely that the bankruptcy process will be lengthy and that appeals will further delay the distribution of compensation. Because litigation against Dow Corning in the United States is currently stayed, a group of test cases against the Dow group of companies is being pursued in Victoria. Also involved in the litigation are Dow Corning's subsidiary companies, including the local company, Dow Corning Australia.

Cases have been entered into the major torts list, a program established recently to manage the cases that involved serious legal issues and injuries. The cases are being managed by Mr Justice Hedigan of the Supreme Court. He will make orders with which all parties must comply and ensure that the cases move efficiently through the court processes.

There are other American manufacturers involved—3M, Baxter and BMS. Because of the collapse of the global settlement fund, alternative strategies must be devised for clients with implants from these manufacturers. Currently test cases are being sought to be tried in the District Court of Texas. It is unlikely that they are going to be dealt with before early 1997.
Australian women are entitled to equity on this. I seek the support of other members in the House on what I see as a major injustice being perpetrated upon Australian women in this case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vale, Danna, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —More than 250,000 Australians suffer from the serious effects of dementia. In the next 20 years, the number will double. It is estimated that only one in 20 dementia sufferers is cared for in dementia‐specific facilities. The majority, 51 per cent, are cared for in their own homes by family members; 37 per cent are cared for in nursing homes; nine per cent are cared for in hostels; and three per cent are cared for in other facilities.

SPEECH.PARA: There can be no doubt that there is a very urgent need to provide specialist care for dementia sufferers because the reality is that Australia is witnessing a crisis in the provision of such care. One of the nation's oldest and most respected aged care providers, the Hammond Care Group, is based in my electorate of Hughes. The Hammond Care Group provides residential and day care to elders at the Hammond Village at Hammondville, which is an adjoining suburb of Holsworthy.

The Hammond Care Group has a well deserved reputation for delivering effective and high quality programs which enable older adults to maximise and improve their quality of life, and for its continuing commitment to providing for those dementia sufferers who are least able to provide for themselves. The Hammond village facility provides day care, hostel and nursing home facilities for more than 400 aged residents—about half of whom suffer from Alzheimer's disease and other forms of dementia. This excellent facility includes three nursing homes, two of which are general nursing homes of 78 beds and one dementia‐specific nursing home of 72 beds.

The Hammond Care Group's newest hostel is the Meadows, which, as a purpose designed dementia‐specific hostel, is unlike any other in Australia and is gaining worldwide acclaim as a centre of excellence in dementia care. This purpose designed hostel provides for 40 people, including one respite place. The Hammond village facility includes a general hospital for 100 people as well as two respite places and self-care and supported self-care cottages for 50 people.

There is also a day care and respite centre called Gabrielle's for the elderly still living in the community. Gabrielle's also conducts a carers education program and is establishing a healthy aged program. The facility also includes a respite care program for five people requiring home care and a day therapy service, an allied health service and a volunteer program.

The Hammond Care Group is a leader in the provision of professional advice and expertise to other aged care organisations, and the organisation is successfully working with other aged care providers to meet this urgent need both in Australia and overseas such as in South-East Asia, North America and Europe. This is evidenced by the fact that the Commonwealth Department of Health and Family Services has selected the Hammond Care Group to provide training in dementia care to 500 nursing homes and hostels in New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory as part of the government's national action plan for dementia care. I am proud that the Hammond Care Group, a world leading provider in dementia care, is within my electorate of Hughes.

I also want to bring to the attention of this honourable House that this important dementia care facility is potentially under the flight paths of the airport which may or may not be established at Holsworthy. The Hammond village facility is adjacent to the Holsworthy defence area. As far as people with dementia are concerned, close proximity to an international airport is a situation which could adversely affect their lives to a far greater degree than that of ordinary healthy citizens.

The Chief Executive of the Hammond Care Group, Dr Stephen Judd, said to me the other day, `Noise is to dementia sufferers what stairs are to people in wheelchairs.' Noise disables, disorientates, disturbs and increases agitation. Whatever other compelling reasons there may be for saying no to an airport at Holsworthy, our compassion for those who in our community are old and suffer from the disabling disease of dementia should be one of the most compelling considerations of all. That a dementia care provider of the standard of excellence maintained by the Hammond Care Group at Hammondville may be located under the flight paths of an international airport is not only a disgrace but also an obscene waste of a desperately needed resource.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take this opportunity to oppose the Crimes Amendment (Controlled Operations) Bill. I do not intend to vote against it; I just want to record my concerns. I congratulate the Attorney‐General, Daryl Williams. I think that this bill is an improvement on the one that was put forward by the Australian Labor Party. But it is simply naive if the Attorney‐General believes that he has put in safeguards that are not going to see the Commonwealth police become very large‐scale drug dealers in this country. The all‐pervading power of drugs and the money that is involved have had a very corrosive effect on public confidence. I believe that it has to be tackled as a whole issue, not in this piecemeal way of giving the police ever‐increasing powers.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite clear to me that the power the police will obtain will be abused. Why do I say that? Because the power of the police is always abused. All power corrupts, and absolute power corrupts absolutely. The West Australian a few days ago had as a headline that Western Australian police are the most corrupt in Australia. I do not believe that. I do not think it is true at all. I think there are elements of corruption which pervade the whole police system and the whole judicial system in Australia. What we need in Australia is not a royal commission—I think the royal commissioners themselves are, sadly, tainted—but a public inquiry into all aspects of the administration of justice.

When I look at the justice system in Western Australia, which I know well, I find it is quite clear that there has been collusion between the prosecution and the police to hide evidence, to falsify evidence, to put forward stuff that they know to be untrue. That, of course, is in total breach of the duty of the prosecution, whose responsibility is to put forward all the evidence and only the evidence. As the High Court has observed, if a prosecutor deviates from this course, he becomes a very powerful unsworn witness for the prosecution. This has happened, sadly, all too often in Western Australia and, I suspect, throughout Australia.

I have here a paper entitled, `Peeling the onion of Long Bay', written by a friend of mine who was actually on remand in Long Bay at the time, under outrageous circumstances. I believe that half a million dollars—his dollars—later, he has been justified. But it is quite clear that there are people in Long Bay because they were set up by the police. The police have awesome powers to fabricate evidence; to set up people. The thing which is driving this, of course, is the corrupting money of drugs. If we are going to do something about this, we have to look at the thing as a whole. I believe that if we were serious about it—and I do not believe for one moment that we are—what we would be doing is legalising and controlling the distribution of these drugs to take the money out.

The only way to deal with the big operators, at the big end of town—which this bill is supposed to attack and simply will not—is to take away the profit margin. If you raise the risk, you raise the margins, and the big operators enhance their profits.I believe that it is quite possible to supply drugs on prescription to known addicts at a price which would pay for their cost. After all, most of these drugs are very cheap to produce. It would take away the profit motive. In my view, in that way that industry could be killed stone dead. If there are a few people whose addiction is enhanced by this greater availability, that is a price I would be very happy to pay to do away with the all‐corroding effect of drugs on the legal system in Australia. I think it is something that is going to have to be faced up to. I do not see either the government or the opposition facing up to it.

It does not just stop at drugs. It pervades the whole legal system. I believe there is evidence of this in the Family Court which, in my view, is an abomination that seeks to be legal. I have a case in Western Australia of a woman who is being unmercifully hounded and harassed by the Family Court. She has lost a fortune, which was a fortune that she brought to the marriage. There is also the matter of the behaviour of the judge in this case. I go through the transcripts, and I get briefings from the civil liberties people, and the behaviour of the judge is beyond belief. The woman has been bashed up in the car park on a couple of occasions, obviously by people who have a vested interest in making sure she does not succeed in her case.

One wonders where these things are going to end. I will not be voting against this bill; my vote will be pointless. I want it on the record that I think this bill is dangerous and it sets a dangerous precedent. It will give powers to the Federal Police that will be abused. If anyone thinks that the Federal Police are any different from the state police, I think they are very sadly mistaken. I want it on the record that this bill will not achieve what it sets out to do. There is a possibility that it will in fact do very little, or nothing. There is a risk, in my view, that it will lead to even greater corruption of the police forces, and the judiciary, I might add, than already exists today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sercombe, Bob,MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) commented on matters that all of us in this place need to take very seriously. Whilst I do not concur with the conclusions he reaches at this stage, nonetheless, the matters he raises are sufficiently serious, I think, for the parliament to continue to keep this particular item of legislation, and other similar items of legislation, under review to ensure that the abuses that he envisages arising from it are nipped in the bud at the earliest possible opportunity. Later, in what will be a fairly short speech on this matter, I will talk more about that.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it might be useful to go back over some of the background to how this particular bill arises. It arises out of a case in the High Court known as the Ridgeway case. As I understand it, the circumstances of that particular case are that a man named Ridgeway formed an association in prison, in South Australia in the 1980s, with another prisoner called Lee. When Lee was released, he became an informer for the police in Malaysia. Subsequent to that, Ridgeway established contact with Lee, with the intention of importing heroin into Australia. In that context, with Lee as an informer for the Malaysian police, the Malaysian police and Australian Federal Police cooperated in what was called a controlled operation where the police were involved in the importation of heroin in order to obtain convictions, presumably not just of Ridgeway but further up the food chain in relation to drug distribution.

Of course, the problem for the police was the relevant section of the Customs Act that provides that any person who imports or attempts to import into Australia any prohibited import to which the section applies shall be guilty of an offence. Ridgeway was convicted but the High Court, on appeal, ultimately upheld his appeal on the basis that evidence associated with the controlled operation should have been excluded under the discretion of the court to exclude evidence on public policy grounds—that is, the court could exclude evidence obtained by unlawful means. The justices of the High Court stated that if law enforcement officials were to be exempted from the law that would be a matter for the parliament and not for the courts. The High Court also made the finding that police have no special immunity from the criminal law and that if criminal offences are committed during an investigation that could taint evidence to the extent that a judge could exclude that evidence.

The bill arises from the quite reasonable desire of the former government and this current government to clarify the position and the protections available to law enforcement officers in the sorts of circumstances they found themselves in in the Ridgeway matter. The nature of drug offences and the corrosive influences of that particular sort of activity which the member for Kalgoorlie referred to are well known and the involvement of organised crime in those sorts of activities does require perhaps more novel, innovative ways, including controlled operations, of addressing that sort of crime. So the essential issue before the parliament, as the member for Kalgoorlie indicated, is the nature of the protections that are available if police are to be conferred with some sort of immunity from the criminal law in relation to what would perhaps be, in other circumstances, slightly unconventional actions they may take with respect to investigations in this area.

There are three substantial protections in the legislation. One is a protection substantially from police entrapping individuals. Clause 15I(2) of the bill, for example, provides that the exemption of law enforcement officers from certain offences does not apply if the conduct of the officer involves intentionally inducing the person targeted to commit an offence and the person would not otherwise have had the intent to commit the offence. Therefore, there is protection against the quite legitimate concern about entrapment that could arise.

A further fundamental provision is that the bill makes it quite clear that the discretion of courts to exclude evidence in criminal proceedings or to stay criminal proceedings in the interests of justice is not limited by the operation of this bill. I suppose the other very significant protection that exists for civil liberties and for ensuring that there are some barriers to the sort of police conduct that the member for Kalgoorlie was concerned about is in section 15S of the bill, where the authorising officer, whether that be an AFP officer or a customs officer, needs to report to the minister in question about the action taken; that is, there is a provision that, within three months after a certificate authorising a controlled operation ceases to be in force, the officer must give to the minister a written report stating whether or not the controlled operation authorised by the certificate was carried out.

If the operation was carried out, the report must provide considerable detail about the operation, which I do not propose, in the interests of brevity, to go into. Finally, there is a provision in the bill for the minister to table the report before parliament with respect to the controlled operations and some of the circumstances surrounding it. It seems to me on balance that those protections are not only desirable but, I hope, adequate. But they need, as I started off by saying, to be continually reviewed by this parliament to ensure that undesirable consequences do not arise in conferring these sorts of powers on police officers.

One of the issues that did arise in debate last year was that the present Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) argued, as I understand it, in the House of Representatives that there should be a judicial officer, a judge, involved in the issuing of a certificate to authorise police to carry out controlled operations with immunity from liability. It is interesting that last year the Attorney‐General did argue for that particular additional protection. I notice that in the Senate at the end of last month, when this bill was dealt with, Senator Vanstone, on behalf of the government, indicated her understanding that judges being involved in the criminal investigation process could well invalidate court proceedings at a later date in relation to the matters that the judges had been involved in. That is clearly a very serious matter that the parliament needs to ensure it does not transgress on.

In relation to the question of judicial involvement in the issue of certificates, I notice also that Mr Rozenes, of the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions, in giving evidence to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee on this matter last year, had the following things to say:

There is no comparison, in my view, between the role that is required to be performed by the grantor of the certificate in this investigative exercise with that which is reposed in the federal court judge, or the magistrate, or whatever it is who gives a warrant for either listening devices, or search warrants, or anything else, where there is a clear requirement that there be balanced the interests of the citizen who is about to have his property turned upside down, his premises invaded, his body samples taken, or his voice listened to, monitored, reported and recorded, on the one hand, and law enforcement requirements on the other. There, there is genuine balancing of competing public interest which requires additional involvement. But even that is currently the subject matter of challenge in the High Court and may, or may not, survive that case. In these situations, there is no competing private right or interest that needs to be balanced against the law enforcement requirement.

These are matters of very great constitutional substance which I do not propose to go into in this particular debate, except to say that, because they are of such substance and because the powers that are being conferred on law enforcement officers in these matters are so substantial, I believe there is an obligation on this parliament at some time—and I am not sure whether it is appropriate at this stage to specify the time, but at some reasonable time in the future—to have a look at the way in which these particular provisions have operated to ensure that they are operating satisfactorily, the appropriate balances are in place and there is not abuse by our law enforcement organisations of the trust that has been placed in them. In that context, the question of judicial review ought to be revisited, in my opinion, and that ought to form a basis for a further report to parliament.

On balance, this is a bill that, for the reasons I mentioned before—the nature of drug offences, the nature of organised crime involvement in drug offences—does require measures that perhaps some of us would be uncomfortable with in other circumstances. However, it is not a matter that the parliament ought to confer and then forget about. These are powers that the parliament ought to review in the not too distant future to ensure that all the appropriate protections are in place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I apologise for my delayed appearance before the Main Committee. I was chairing the Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs. One of the problems of the parliament at the moment is that one seems to be required to be in so many places at the same time. I thank the former minister opposite for his courtesy.

SPEECH.PARA: It is always refreshing in the parliament when we find pieces of legislation which are supported by all parties. It is not widely recognised in the Australian community just how often the political parties and both sides of parliament agree when changes to the law are necessary. Quite often in the area of the attorney‐general and justice portfolio this is the case.

The honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) was the minister who was originally responsible for the legislative response to the Ridgeway case. The Ridgeway case was one of those High Court decisions where the court threw back to the parliament a problem which had to be solved through legislative amendment. It ought to be recognised that this bill is a considered response, having been introduced by the previous government and referred to a Senate committee. Suggested amendments were made by that committee and accepted by the new government. We now find ourselves debating the Crimes Amendment (Controlled Operations) Bill 1996.

The facts in Ridgeway are actually quite interesting. The case R. v. Ridgeway concerned an operation in which officers of the Australian Federal Police were involved in the importation of a trafficable quantity of heroin. In the High Court, Justice McHugh recited the facts of Ridgeway as follows:

[Ridgeway] was released from prison in February 1989. In September and October 1989, he travelled to Singapore under a false name and in breach of his parole conditions. In Singapore, he met Lee and solicited him to import heroin into Australia. Unbeknown to . . . [Ridgeway], Lee had become an informer for the Royal Malaysian Police Force. The officer who `ran' Lee was Thian Soo Chong, an Assistant Superintendent of Police. Lee kept Superintendent Chong informed of his dealings with Ridgeway. In turn, Superintendent Chong alerted Superintendent Butler, an Australian Federal Police Officer stationed in Kuala Lumpur, as to the plans of . . . [Ridgeway]. With the knowledge, if not the encouragement of the Australian Federal Police, Superintendent Chong and Lee purchased heroin in north Malaysia for about $4000 on 18 December 1989 for the purposes of delivering it to . . . [Ridgeway] in Australia.

. . . Arrangements were made by members of the Australian Federal Police and the Royal Malaysian Police Force for Superintendent Chong and Lee to travel to Australia carrying the heroin in a plastic bag inside a tissue box which was in a camera bag. Australian Federal Police officers took steps to ensure that Superintendent Chong—who was carrying the heroin—was not searched or detained by Australian Customs officers.
History records that Ridgeway was later arrested by the Australian Federal Police, after having purchased the heroin.

Over the years, Mr Deputy Speaker, law enforcement officers in this country have used covert operations to monitor illegal narcotics dealings, to track them through customs and then to apprehend those involved in importation, possession and other offences. The circumstances in this case are, however, quite different. Law enforcement officers themselves were involved in importing heroin for the purposes of apprehending Ridgeway.

The Bills Digest has a very effective dissection of the provisions of the bill. When one looks at what is proposed, one has to accept that the legislation we are debating contains an appropriate balance. The High Court decision, therefore, was to the effect that, where law enforcement officials themselves committed an element of the offence for which a defendant is subsequently prosecuted, then as a general rule a court should exercise its discretion to refuse to allow evidence of that element of the offence to be admitted against the defendant. A certain number of the judges—Sir Anthony Mason, Mr Justice Deane and Mr Justice Dawson—indicated that, if law enforcement officers are to engage in unlawful conduct in the course of investigations, then a legislative scheme authorising this conduct would need to be established. The genesis of the original bill was, no doubt, the suggestions by those three learned High Court judges that this parliament needed to plug what was obviously an unintended consequence of the law as it existed at the time the Ridgeway facts occurred.

The main elements of the bill allow the commissioner, the deputy commissioners and the assistant commissioners of the Australian Federal Police and members of the National Crime Authority to issue certificates authorising a controlled law enforcement operation involving the import, export and/or possession of narcotic drugs.The bill also provides that certain law enforcement officers, acting in good faith and in the course of duty in relation to an authorised controlled operation, are not criminally liable for certain offences against section 233B of the Customs Act 1901 or offences against sections 10 to 14 of the Crimes (Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances) Act 1990—that relate to the possession, importation or exportation of narcotics—and associated offences, such as conspiracy, aiding and abetting, and in some cases state and territory offences relating to the possession of narcotic substances and associated offences.

The bill also provides that the fact that law enforcement officials took part in, or facilitated, the importation of narcotics prior to the commencement of the bill is not to render evidence of that importation inadmissible, where the importation was made pursuant to a request from the Australian Federal Police to the Australian Customs Service for an exemption from detailed customs scrutiny. The bill also includes procedures which will contain the usage of controlled operations to instances involving the investigation or detection of, or the prosecution of persons for, serious criminal activity.

The bill seeks to, in fact, bring in a balanced regime to enable the law enforcement officers of the Commonwealth to carry out their duties. Clearly, one of the great tragedies in Australia is the level of importation of drugs and the devastating effect that drugs have on our youth and on others who have become addicted to them. Consequently, the parliament must always consider community benefit.

At times, I am concerned when there are elements of retrospectivity in relation to legislation. Civil liberties should be preserved. It ought to be noted, though, that this particular bill provides a number of very important protections. So the balance has been maintained. Some in the community may criticise the government for not having got the balance exactly right, but I believe that the government is entitled to be praised not only for continuing with this particular piece of legislation but also for incorporating the amendments suggested by the Senate. It ought to be recognised that a person cannot be convicted if, in fact, the person only committed the offence because of the actions of the federal law enforcement officers. So, to be found guilty a person must have been a person who was going to commit an offence anyway.

I commend the government and I commend the opposition for continuing to support the government on this issue. As I have said, this is a bill which is supported by both sides of the parliament. It is a bill which, I believe, is in the interests of the Australian community. It is a bill that sends a message to drug traffickers that this country is not going to be soft on drugs or crime. The parliament is seeking to protect Australians from the evil of drugs while ensuring that safeguards are maintained in our law so that people are treated fairly, properly and equitably. I commend the bill to the Main Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr, Duncan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This concludes one of the most passionate debates that has existed not so much within the parliament as within the community of those concerned about the way in which we deal with our response to the balance between the right of law enforcement and the protection of civil liberties within our community.

SPEECH.PARA: As the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) has rightly indicated, I was minister at the time the High Court brought down its decision in the Ridgeway case. The member for Fisher has set out the background to that litigation, so there is no need to canvass it again. In short, the parliament was then faced with a choice as to whether or not it would facilitate what had been a traditional policing practice of being involved in controlled operations in the area of drug importations or to, in a sense, do nothing and thereby end what was our advice at the time as to what was the most effective way of dealing not against the small players in the international drug trade but rather against the Mr Bigs, the people who were the principal sponsors of the drug trade.

Briefly, that dilemma arises because a capacity to involve law enforcement in controlled operations is absent. Whenever the police found a courier with a small amount of some drug—or with a large amount of drug—they would be limited in what they could do. In a controlled operation, they seek to enlist the aid of that courier—to `turn' that courier—to follow those drugs and create an operation designed to sting the principal organiser of the scheme, and to follow the drug trail as far up the line as possible.

All the advice I received as minister at the time was that, without the capacity to undertake controlled operations, we would in a sense be limited to arresting the small players in the game. Often they were individuals who were driven to extremity, perhaps by their own addiction or by their own greed, but they were essentially small players in the game against those who are really the professionals, the Mr Bigs of the system.

I believed it was important for us to deal with the High Court decision in a way which enabled that law enforcement obligation to be continued. I said at the time, in introducing the Crimes Amendment (Controlled Operations) Bill, that good law enforcement is a citizen's entitlement. I made the point that loss of confidence in law enforcement would lead governments to measures destructive of civil liberties. I indicated that I did not believe that this bill was such a measure and I said that the choice, in my view, was between a society prepared to accept balanced legislation to counter criminals and a society poisoned by the conditions created by those criminals and their activities. I made the point that the bill set out a full and open system of accountability which required reports to the responsible minister and, in turn, reports to the parliament.

It is fair to say that those views were certainly not universally accepted by a significant component of those practising at the criminal bar. From their ranks was organised a coalition—I think it was called the Ridgeway coalition—which sought to influence members of this House to oppose the measures which I introduced. There has been within the House, on both sides of the parliament—the coalition parties and our own side—a very heightened awareness of the need to ensure that, in considering this bill, all the civil liberties issues that were raised by the Ridgeway coalition were properly taken into account and included, in so far as they could be, in the considerations that have occurred to date in the construction of this legislation.

It pleases me that, after the process of parliamentary scrutiny, a Senate inquiry and a change of government, the bill finds its way back into the House in substantially the same form as I introduced it. It pleases me because it vindicates what I took to be the proper balance at the time; a balance which was then in some contention but which has survived one of the most rigorous processes of examination of any legislation in the parliamentary system.

In these remarks, I place on record my particular thanks to Senator Barney Cooney for his work as chair, not only of the Senate committee which examined this legislation but also of the caucus committee on legal and constitutional affairs for many years. He is a person with whom I have had some fierce arguments. He is a person given to strong views, particularly on the subject of civil liberties. In the role that I had to fulfil as Minister for Justice, it was inevitable that, from time to time, we would have a contest of ideas which would require us to test each other's assumptions and test the propositions that we were each making in terms of our advocacies to each other.

I want to record my very sincere and deep gratitude to Senator Cooney for the work he put into his consideration of government legislation coming before him, both in the caucus committee and in his role as chair of the Senate committee. I believe that the work of this parliament is immeasurably enhanced by parliamentarians of the calibre of Senator Cooney, who have not risen to ministerial rank—and now, with the change of government, are not likely to do so—but whose contribution to this parliament and to Australia generally needs to be recognised on occasions like this.

Might I also, because he is sitting next to me at the moment, mention my colleague the member for Banks (Mr Melham), with whom I have also had some fierce contests. It would be no surprise to members of this House to know that the member for Banks took a view contrary to that which I proposed at the time and contested that view fiercely. I believe, also, that this is the place where those arguments can be tested and where the willingness of members to run against the grain of what their own government is doing from time to time is to be valued.

There have also been occasions where the member for Banks and I have very much been on the same side. In pulling out materials today for this debate, I inadvertently pulled out a copy of the Crimes (Investigation of Commonwealth Offences) Amendment Bill 1990, which has a similar title to the one we are debating today. I thought I was getting a transcript of what I had said on this legislation earlier, but I pulled this from the computer. That was legislation about which the member for Banks and I had a dialogue with the then Attorney‐General, Mr Duffy, which resulted in very substantial improvements to the way in which records of interview were conducted—the videotaping of them and the limiting of time.

These were measures which many then involved in law enforcement said would result in a limitation on the ability of law enforcement to do its task, but which, as events have transpired, have not had that effect at all. In fact, they are now universally seen as measures which have improved the accountability of the way the police operate and the effectiveness of policing. Certainly, they have meant that there is far less challenge to the admissibility of confessional evidence, and very much less contest about the way in which police are alleged to have extorted that evidence from people, in improper circumstances.

So the member for Banks and I do find common ground on some issues. If I want to flatter myself, I would say that I took a firmer civil liberties position with respect to that, although we were both on the same side. We succeeded in persuading the then Attorney‐General to our point of view, to the benefit, I think, of the Australian community generally.

I record my thanks to Barney Cooney and admit my respect for the fierce opposition that was provided to me and to the member for Banks, who managed to hedge me in and cause me enormous frustration and delay, and from time to time some little annoyance at the way in which he was able to contest this field of ideas at the time.

I do think it is a little bit of a pity that we were not able to pass this legislation before the expiry of the last term of parliament. We did give it a T category status, which meant the highest priority for legislation, but the then opposition in the Senate declined to avail us of the opportunity of passage of that legislation. The consequence of that is that, although we are now rectifying a situation which needed to be rectified, a number of then pending prosecutions have failed; a number of major drug importation prosecutions failed in that interim period when this legislation was not in place.

I wish to put on record my regret that the then shadow minister, Senator Vanstone, did not grasp the seriousness of this issue and that the coalition was not in a position to support legislation which it now brings again before the House. That delay has led to some unfortunate miscarriages of justice, not in a technical legal sense but in a practical sense, where the evidence against persons alleged to be guilty of crimes could not be brought before the court because of the Ridgeway decision—a matter we are now correcting with respect to future and still pending prosecutions.

So that delay has had some serious consequences from the point of view of the community at large. That said, I do join with the member for Fisher to say that I am pleased with the bipartisanship that was ultimately shown. I record that the now Attorney‐General, the member for Tangney (Mr Williams), did indicate when this bill first came before the House his support for it in general terms, a position which is now endorsed by his carriage of this legislation back into the parliament.

I think I need say no more. In debates in 1995 I set out my reasons for support of this legislation in some detail and also contested some of the arguments that were then made about the appropriateness of approvals being given by judges, a view I still adhere to in principle, in the sense that I do not believe that with a separation of powers this is an appropriate task to designate to judges, and also in technical legal black‐letter law a task which I believe it is incompetent to devolve upon judges, given the decisions of the High Court in recent litigation.

This is one of these rare occasions where one can say that after fierce contest one feels vindicated. I am delighted that I am able to stand here and say that I initiated this legislation. It has undergone an ordeal of fire. It has passed that ordeal and I believe that it has passed it to the benefit of the Australian community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly to the Crimes Amendment (Controlled Operations) Bill 1996 and also to indicate that a number of members have some concerns about the procedures that are being used by the government in relation to the introduction of bills or their second reading speeches in the Main Committee rather than in the House of Representatives chamber. It is a matter we will be endeavouring to change, to reform, because we consider that not to be in the best interests of a democratic and properly functioning House of Representatives. As a former member of the Procedure Committee, I have some serious concerns about it, having spent some time considering it when the Main Committee was being debated as a proposal of the Procedure Committee—in other words, during its formative debates. The role of the Main Committee was something that was in a sense quite distinctly different from what has evolved in more recent times as a result of the use of the Main Committee for second reading speeches in the first instance with subsequent debate more or less occurring simultaneously.

SPEECH.PARA: I would agree with other speakers that the bill is a useful bill and it is an important adjunct to the role and the functions of modern police and narcotics detection. It is something that is absolutely critical at a time when the Economist magazine, in its edition of 8 June this year, made some quite interesting comments in relation to offences in Australia that are, in my view, directly related to the growth of drug trafficking within our community. It made the comments in relation to what are perceived to be the criminal trends in the United States of America, which is often portrayed by the media as being the crime capital of the Western world. It made some interesting comments on a survey that was conducted by the ministry of justice in the Netherlands in 1992. It says:

America is no more criminal than other countries. According to an international crime survey carried out by the Ministry of Justice in the Netherlands in 1992, America is not obviously more criminal than anywhere else. You are more likely to be burgled in Australia or New Zealand; you are more likely to be robbed with violence in Spain; you are more likely to be robbed without violence in Spain, Canada, Australia and New Zealand.
Perhaps this next part is not strictly related to drug trafficking, but it adds:
You are more likely to be raped or indecently assaulted in Canada, Australia or Western Germany.

I make these comments because Australia's crime statistics are becoming a matter of serious concern. It is quite clear that the community is now demanding greater concentration on the part not only of their state governments, who have the immediate jurisdiction for criminal investigations, but also—in relation to drug trafficking and all of its `subsidiary industries'—on the part of the Australian federal government. This is because, in the first instance, the Australian federal government has responsibilities in relation to the importation and subsequent trafficking of narcotics across state jurisdictions and the like.

As a member of the Joint Standing Committee on the National Crime Authority for six years—and I note that the member for Banks (Mr Melham) was a former colleague of mine on that committee—I can say that we have spent inordinate amounts of time looking at the way in which the National Crime Authority has been somewhat confounded in the past, due to operational requirements relating to joint operations with state police forces and the Australian Federal Police. We have also looked at, for instance, the very important report that was tabled a couple of years ago on Commonwealth law enforcement agencies and future criminal trends, and at the resourcing of Commonwealth law enforcement agencies in the future as a consequence.

As a continuing member of the Joint Standing Committee on the National Crime Authority, it is my view that some of the cuts foreshadowed in recent times for the forthcoming federal budget are a matter of some concern, whereas there is no doubt that, owing to the fiscal irresponsibility of the previous Labor administration, there is a substantial requirement for cost cutting on the part of the federal government—a matter that a vast majority of the community would no doubt agree with. The overwhelming victory by the coalition government bears testimony to the fact that there is a perception and a belief that the spending of the Commonwealth government was out of hand.

Nonetheless, across‐the‐board spending cuts are dangerous in that they are often blind to the more important necessities, particularly in areas such as this, where we have national criminal investigation agencies—the AFP and the NCA—which are facing, and are already undertaking, cuts to their administrative operations that are going to impinge on the fight against crime, drug trafficking and the insidious influence of organised crime within our community generally.

These are matters of concern, and I have indicated them already to the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams). This is something that I feel very strongly about. In particular, coming as I do from the state of Western Australia—as does the Attorney‐General—I am conscious that we are faced with particular problems that are, let us say, a consequence of our geography, the most notable feature of which is the large coastline of Western Australia.

BREAK.PARA: There is believed to be, through Western Australia's frontier—our international frontier—a regular annual importation into the country of drugs of some $1 billion in value. For instance, it was calculated in recent times that in a 100‐kilometre radius of Geraldton some $300 million worth of drugs were smuggled into Australia in the past few years. I might add that, at the same time, the Comptroller‐General of Customs at the Geraldton wharves was complaining that he had no video surveillance of activity on the wharves; a surveillance which I would have thought would have been absolutely critical to any law enforcement operation that was really going to have an effect on the importation of drugs into our community.

I made those comments at the beginning because a lot of offences that are occurring within our community today—particularly break and enter, stealing and robbery—are mostly drug related. Often, addicts are stealing property from ordinary citizens to feed their habits. Our state police forces are under extraordinary stress as a consequence.

We know that in recent years the various state governments, particularly when they have been coalition governments, have had their own budgetary requirements to cut costs. We have seen reductions in real terms of budgets for the various state police forces, and in particular this impinges on the opportunities for full‐scale joint operations with Commonwealth law enforcement agencies. So there is a compounding effect of the cuts on the federal scene, the cuts on the state scene and the fact that we are witnessing an explosion of drug trafficking within our community, stimulated to some extent by our proximity to the South‐East Asian region.

I was privileged to be able to attend a recent conference in Sydney, organised jointly by the National Crime Authority and the Australian Federal Police, on organised crime within the South‐East Asian and Asian region. I was fascinated to hear some of the comments of law enforcement officers from our neighbouring countries. The former minister would know that I have been a critic at times because there were some restrictions placed on exchange of information between our national law enforcement agencies and some of their counterparts overseas as a consequence of policy decisions by the Australian federal government which I believed were quite extraordinary under the circumstances.

One of those was that, where a jurisdiction overseas had, for instance, capital punishment on its statute books for a particular offence and where a person had been apprehended and interviewed and charged over an offence that involved a capital offence, Australia would restrict the information that would be passed on about this person's antecedents and possible connections, as a consequence of an Australian point of view on the relative severity of that penalty. In my view, that is a reverse form of chauvinism which implies that Australia's criminal code and its criminal justice system are somehow superior to those of other jurisdictions in our region. But it was in fact an impediment to the free exchange of information that would help the fight against organised crime and in particular against organised drug trafficking, in my view the greatest criminal evil facing our nation at present.

I am sure that anyone who is a parent of children in today's community knows only too well the incipient fear at all times of the threat that their child may one day indulge in or experiment in drug consumption. In recent times we have seen some quite horrific stories where younger children—younger juveniles, let us say—are becoming involved in drug consumption at an earlier age. In fact, I recollect that when I was a police officer in Western Australia between 1979 and 1987 I came across one instance of amphetamine consumption by a Western Australian offender in my contacts. But, not that many years later, we were seeing instances where high school students were consuming amphetamines by injection on school premises. This is a quite extraordinary development; a trend that has to be reversed and a trend that requires not only sustained funding for our federal law enforcement agencies but also an increase which recognises the compounding, cascading effect throughout the community of this great evil that drug trafficking represents.

At the beginning I mentioned some of my concerns and those of some of my Independent colleagues in relation to the processes of the House of Representatives. We have seen at the beginning of the parliamentary session a statement, following on from statements made during the election campaign, regarding the changes to our processes to make the House of Representatives a better functioning, more relevant and more democratic place in which the members can represent their constituents to the best effect. I took these statements in good faith, as I am sure many others did, and I believe that these changes are absolutely critical. We must ensure at all times that, where the executive is misusing the processes of the House of Representatives, they must be resisted by all members—not just Independent members but all members—who value the hard‐fought rights of the representatives in the chamber as representatives for their constituents.

We can do no more for our constituents than ensure their rights are preserved. We know that, in recent years, there has been a very strong perception that not only is the debate in the House of Representatives largely irrelevant to the processes of government but also the government regards it in that vein and treats it accordingly. In relation to this bill, in relation to other bills, in relation to the processes of the House of Representatives and in relation to the processes of the Main Committee, the House must assert the rights of its members over the rights of the executive to ensure that it is more relevant and answerable to the people.

I can recollect sitting as a member of the coalition opposition and saying the same things. Unfortunately, as an Independent member, I am now seeing some of the traits of executive superiority being asserted over the rights of the members of the House of Representatives yet again. I hope that we can hold or push that back, because, at the end of the day, it suits everybody that that should take place. We must see the rights of members of the House of Representatives restored to their rightful place.

As a consequence, last sitting week, my colleague the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) moved that a number of the bills be proceeded with further in the House of Representatives chamber. I will be making a similar move shortly, in relation to the next bill.
