But I wanted to emphasise those points in the first instance, just to demonstrate why we are taking on this particular responsibility in the House of Representatives and in the Main Committee and why we believe that the reforms that were proposed by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), in good faith, should be undertaken all the way through to the end of their meaning.

Of course, one of those reforms related to the independent status of the Speaker of the House of Representatives, something that I am sure the member for Calare (Mr Andren), other members and I view as being extremely important. As a consequence, we are anxious to ensure that the House of Representatives supports that role and ensures that it is enhanced in all of its activities.

Finally, I think the bill is one, as the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) indicated, which is deserving of bipartisan support. But I want to repeat those words of caution I said at the beginning. These amendments are all very well. But, at the end of the day, when our national law enforcement agencies are suffering substantial cuts in their operational ability, a lot of these sorts of changes—as noteworthy and as appropriate as they are—are less significant, because the agencies are less able to use the tools, the abilities and the resources, because of the infringements forced on them by the cuts to their budgets. I commend the bill to the Main Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull, David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all those who have taken part in this debate today. In summing up, there are a couple of responses I would like to make.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham) referred to the possible dangers involved when police are empowered to authorise otherwise unlawful conduct by police. The accountability package in the bill will prevent abuse of the process. Frankly, if we are to have any hope of bringing major narcotics traffickers to justice, we must give police adequate powers.

Narcotics trafficking is big money. It is a high risk industry. In such an environment, the possibility for attempts to corrupt police will always exist. But the way to prevent corruption is not to deny police the powers contained in this bill. It is to build in effective accountability mechanisms and safeguards against the abuses of power. The power to authorise controlled operations will lie with 12 senior experienced law enforcement officers: nine in the AFP and three in the NCA. These officers will be responsible to the parliament and the public for the conduct of these operations.

Openness and accountability are central to the framework established by the bill. The bill requires a detailed report to be made to the minister at the time of the decision to authorise an operation. That is, of course, contained in the proposed section 15R. The bill will also require a detailed report to be made about what happened during and after the operation; that is contained in section 15S. In addition, the Australian Federal Police are subject to a strict disciplinary regime and are subject to disciplinary and criminal penalties for misconduct under both the AFP Act and the AFP (Discipline) Regulations.

I turn now to the comments made by the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell). He said that the proposed power will encourage corruption. Frankly, if we are to have any hope of bringing narcotics traffickers to justice, we must give police the adequate powers. The way to prevent corruption is not to deny the police these powers. Commissioner Fitzgerald, in the report of the Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct, concluded that:

The true choice may be between the society altered by legislative or executive action to the extent which is necessary to hamper the misuse of civil privileges by criminals, or a society altered by those criminals and their activities . . . It might be preferable to have a limited qualification of rights so that they can be enjoyed in the freer atmosphere of a fairer more honest and honourable society.
I should also add that an officer who sought to deal in narcotics outside the course of duty would face the normal penalties for narcotics trafficking.

Federal law enforcement officers are already subject to a strict disciplinary regime. Australian Federal Police officers, who will play the leading role in most operations, are subject to disciplinary and criminal penalties for misconduct under both the AFP Act and the AFP (Discipline) Regulations. AFP officers are employed on contract and can be summarily dismissed in cases of misconduct.

The honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Sercombe) proposed that judges authorise the controlled operations. This question was in fact addressed at length during the debate in the Senate. The outcome of the debate was that the Democrats, who had pressed amendments to require judicial authorisation, were persuaded that the proposal was unwise and withdrew the amendments. The difficulties with the proposal were well expressed by Senator Cooney in the debate on 29 May when he said:
I think no judge should be brought before a court and cross‐examined as to why he or she believes that a person is likely to commit an offence.
The honourable member for Maribyrnong also proposed that a parliamentary committee should review the provisions after some years.

The legislation will be reviewed by the courts very soon after it commences operations. There are prosecutions on foot at the moment that will almost certainly result in the testing of provisions. This is a more effective and more immediate form of scrutiny than that which is proposed by the honourable member. The honourable member is also most likely aware that the High Court is at present considering a case which involves debate about the propriety of judges performing non‐judicial functions. I refer to the case involving argument about the appointment of Judge Jane Mathews to conduct the Hindmarsh Bridge inquiry. This is an emerging issue and it would be premature to establish a review mechanism now. It is possible that some kind of major review, possibly by the ALRC or by a parliamentary committee, will be needed once the issues have fully emerged.

The honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) made great play of the possible budget cuts to the NCA. He would know that I can provide no details of any budget proposals involving the NCA or any other agency. Obviously, we must wait for details of the budget which will be delivered on 20 August. However, any cuts to the NCA will in any event be considered in the light of the functions which are performed by the range of Commonwealth and state law enforcement agencies which have a role in the struggle against the importation of illicit narcotics.

The previous government's report, the Review of Commonwealth Law Enforcement Arrangements, identified the need to `eliminate perceived duplications of roles that existed between the NCA and the AFP.' This would offer the opportunity to make savings without an effect upon the performance of functions. The honourable member must not assume that any cuts to the funding of the NCA, if in fact there are any, will necessarily have a negative effect upon the efficiency of the struggle against crime and the importation of illicit narcotics in particular.

Proposed section 15U will require the tendering of the certificate. During the debate in the Senate an amendment to insert a new section 15U, which deals with the tendering of evidentiary certificates, was carried. Such a provision was not included in the bill presented by the government because it was felt to be unnecessary. It is inevitable that the fact of a controlled operation will be apparent to the defence in any trial depending upon such evidence. The defence will then have the right to oppose the admissibility of the evidence by challenging the authorisation procedure. This would be done in most cases by way of a voir dire. However it does not damage the bill to include specific requirements that the prosecution tender the certificate thus putting the defence on notice that evidence resulting from a controlled operation will be adduced.

Section 15U is somewhat imperfect in that the section, on its face, requires that a certificate authorising a controlled operation is to be tendered in evidence in `a prosecution for an offence against section 233B of the Customs Act 1901'. Needless to say, many prosecutions for offences under section 233B of the Customs Act will arise which do not depend on any evidence gathered through a controlled operation. In many cases there will be no certificate to present.

My department is confident that the court will apply commonsense principles of interpretation to the operation of section 15U and will not require the tendering of a certificate in a trial where no controlled operation is being conducted. The requirement to tender the certificate will arise only in those cases where evidence is to be led by the prosecution which has been obtained through the conduct of a controlled operation. I again thank honourable members for their valuable contributions to this debate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 17 June.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull, David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.
I heard the comments made here today by the member for Moore (Mr Filing)—

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: FILING

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

INTERJECT.PARA: That further proceedings on this bill be conducted in the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The minister has the call and shall proceed.

—The comments made today by the honourable member for Moore have basically been highlighting the need for better law enforcement mechanisms and for more resources so that that can be undertaken. Quite frankly, I find it quite extraordinary that he has expressed those concerns but now wants to obstruct the passage of the legislation, which is supported by both the government and the opposition, to give the Commissioner of the AFP very necessary powers to deal with police corruption. His actions are inconsistent with his words. I therefore present the explanatory memorandum of the bill and proceed to the second reading.

SPEECH.PARA: Vigilance against police corruption is an ongoing issue for Australian governments and the public at large. The more important provisions of this bill are focused on ensuring that the Australian Federal Police remains corruption free. A similar bill lapsed earlier this year due to the federal election. The government has decided to introduce a bill in a similar form to provide the necessary armoury to combat corruption within the Australian Federal Police.

Members will be aware that the royal commission into the New South Wales Police Service has uncovered distressing instances of corruption and other serious misconduct. Such abuse of power and of the community's trust can never be tolerated in any police service. I know all members were distressed to hear that serving and former members of the Australian Federal Police have been implicated in corruption and other reprehensible behaviour. The government and the administration of the Australian Federal Police are strongly committed to ensuring that it is never debilitated by a culture of corruption and misconduct.

BREAK.PARA: The institutional culture of a police force is of vital importance to a community. A police force stands at the threshold of the criminal justice system and is in effective control of the enforcement of the criminal law. Each police officer has an extensive authority over all other citizens, coupled with a wide discretion over its exercise. Subsequent stages in the criminal justice process, including courts and prisons, are largely dependent on the activities of police services and will inevitably be affected by their deficiencies.

The Commonwealth is, of course, particularly dependent on the integrity and efficiency of the Australian Federal Police. First, it is the principal agency for the general enforcement of the Commonwealth's criminal laws. It provides a vital link in effective cooperation with international law enforcement bodies. It is essential that the Australian Federal Police maintains the confidence of these bodies as well as the public's confidence.

In 1989, the parliament, with the support of all parties, substantially amended the Australian Federal Police Act 1979. The reforms were designed, in part, to introduce a new and unique employment scheme which would inhibit the occurrence of patterns of corruption uncovered in other police services. One aspect of these reforms was the replacement of tenure with a system of fixed term appointments. Another aspect was providing the commissioner with chief executive powers in relation to appointments within the Australian Federal Police, including the power to end the appointment of any police member or civilian staff member.

One of the principles underlying this employment scheme is that the commissioner should have a clear and specific responsibility for the integrity and operational efficiency of the Australian Federal Police. Naturally, the scheme also envisaged that the commissioner should have the powers and authority necessary to fulfil these responsibilities.

At present, the commissioner's power to terminate the appointment of members or staff members of the Australian Federal Police is subject only to two exceptions. The current legislation states that the commissioner must not make use of this power merely because a disciplinary charge has been or could be laid or a court has convicted or found the person guilty of a criminal offence.

These exceptions were provided in order to separate the Australian Federal Police's disciplinary processes—which can result in dismissal as a penalty for a disciplinary offence—from the commissioner's general power to end a person's appointment. In practice, the limitations on the commissioner's power of dismissal can lead to situations which are clearly inconsistent with the policy aims of the AFP employment scheme. For example, it is not clear that the commissioner can terminate the appointment of a member of the Australian Federal Police even if the member admits publicly that he or she is guilty of corruption or other serious reprehensible behaviour. To dismiss that person from the Australian Federal Police, it might be necessary for the commissioner either to invite the member to resign voluntarily or to initiate disciplinary proceedings.

The commissioner's hands could be equally tied if the person were to be convicted of serious criminal offences by a court. The government believes that this situation is unsatisfactory. Corruption in a police service can seriously undermine the professional self‐respect and morale of the decent and honest police who comprise the majority of members. It can also seriously diminish public confidence in the affected police service, something that may now be apparent in respect of the New South Wales Police Service. Immediate and effective action may be the only way to minimise the harm. On occasions, it will not be desirable to wait for lengthy disciplinary or court proceedings to be finally resolved before taking action.

The proposed amendments will remove the limitations on the commissioner's powers of dismissal which relate to disciplinary offences and criminal convictions. The intention is to give the commissioner a broader and more effective power to end an appointment where the commissioner has lost confidence in a person's suitability for continued employment in the Australian Federal Police. The amendments will, in particular, permit the commissioner to act quickly and decisively to end the appointment of a person where the commissioner believes on reasonable grounds that there has been corruption, serious abuse of power or serious dereliction of duty.

While the government believes it is necessary in the public interest for the commissioner to have a wide discretion to end appointments, it also recognises that the employment rights of individual members and staff members within the Australian Federal Police should also be protected. Currently, members and staff members are protected in two ways in the event that they are retired by the commissioner before the end of their terms of appointment. Firstly, people who are retired may seek judicial review by the Federal Court of the commissioner's decision to end their appointments. Secondly, retired people are entitled to compensation for the lost part of their appointments.

As this bill will widen the scope of the commissioner's powers to end appointments, the government believes it is also reasonable to extend to members and staff members additional remedies against the possibility that the commissioner's power might be exercised unfairly or unreasonably. The government has been at pains to find an appropriate balance between the public interest in maintaining a corruption free Australian Federal Police and the rights of the individual member or staff member who may be retired early either because of allegations of corruption or for other reasons, such as inefficiency.

In particular, in reconsidering this bill, I focused on the need for appropriate safeguards to protect innocent members and staff members. The government has decided that, in addition to the existing protective measures I have outlined, individual members and staff members who have their appointments terminated early will also have access to merit reviews before the Industrial Relations Commission and the Industrial Relations Court. At present, the Australian Federal Police are excluded from those unlawful termination provisions by the industrial relations regulations.

Honourable members will no doubt be aware that, under the government's industrial relations reforms, it is proposed that the Industrial Relations Court be abolished and for the industrial relations jurisdiction to be conferred instead on the Federal Court. The government intends to repeal the relevant industrial relations regulation, subject to transitional and savings provisions, with effect from the date that the amendments in this bill come into force, and that is 28 days after royal assent.

The bill makes one exception to the opening of the unfair dismissal remedies to the Australian Federal Police. This is where serious misconduct is involved. The bill provides that, where a person's appointment has been ended because of their conduct or behaviour, the commissioner may make a declaration that the conduct or behaviour amounts to serious misconduct and that the serious misconduct is having, or is likely to have, a damaging effect on professional self‐respect or morale within the Australian Federal Police or on its reputation with the public or with an Australian or overseas government or law enforcement agency.

Serious misconduct is defined in the bill to mean corruption, serious abuse of power, serious dereliction of duty or any other serious reprehensible behaviour. Where a declaration of this kind is made, the person who has been retired will be excluded from the operation of the Industrial Relations Act provisions concerning unlawful dismissal, and will not be able to obtain merit review. Such persons, however, will retain the present right to compensation for their early retirement and to seek judicial review of the commissioner's declaration, as well as the decision to end their appointment. Also, a person subject to a declaration of serious misconduct will be able to seek a statement of reason in relation to the commissioner's decision to make the declaration.

However, where the reasons would disclose information that would not be in the public interest to disclose—for example, operationally sensitive information such as the identity of informants or current investigations—the Attorney‐General may, in the public interest, issue a certificate under subsection 14(1) of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 preventing disclosure of that information. This solution reaches an appropriate balance between the public interest in maintaining a corruption free Australian Federal Police and the rights of the individual.

As I have indicated, the commissioner will be able to make a declaration only where the commissioner believes on reasonable grounds that there has been serious misconduct by the person who is retired. It is also necessary that the commissioner believes that the serious misconduct is actually damaging, or is likely to damage, the Australian Federal Police in one of the ways I have described.

Clearly, these are special circumstances. They are circumstances in which immediate action by the commissioner is needed to maintain the internal integrity or the public reputation of the Australian Federal Police, and where it is not appropriate that an outside tribunal may be able to remake the commissioner's decision. The amendment will permit the commissioner to make a declaration either before or after the behaviour or conduct in question becomes widely known. This is to allow the commissioner to act to pre‐empt the threatened damage to the morale or reputation of the Australian Federal Police.

The bill also contains several minor amendments concerning two separate matters. One group of amendments is intended to give the Governor‐General the power to authorise the commissioner and the deputy commissioners to appoint or promote persons as commissioned officers with the Australian Federal Police. At present the legislation permits the Governor‐General to give this authority only to the commissioner. The new arrangements are administratively more convenient. The amendments allow for appropriate safeguards.

The second group of amendments deals with the disciplinary obligations of staff members when granted special leave of absence for service with an industrial association. The effect is to extend the existing provisions which deal with members to staff members, as well. I commend the bill to the Main Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports this bill. It is fair to say, I think, that the poor old government does not have much on its plate in the way of legislation so it has been picking up, in the main, the legislation of the previous government, and that is what this bill basically is. Apart from some minor procedural amendments that were made to the 1995 bill, this bill is substantially the bill that the Labor party introduced before the election, and the party supports wholeheartedly an expedited passage of the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been the New South Wales royal commission, which not only disclosed that there has been widespread corruption within the New South Wales police force but also adversely referred to a number of officers of the Australian Federal Police; there has been a parliamentary committee in Western Australia that has recently reported to the Western Australian parliament; and, of course, there was the celebrated Fitzgerald inquiry in Queensland. In the light of all those inquiries, we can no longer say that either the state or the federal police forces are lilywhite. I think it is on that basis that this bill comes before the parliament. It makes it easier for a member or a staff member to be dismissed by reason of serious misconduct, regardless of whether that conduct may amount to a breach of the Australian Federal Police (Discipline) Regulations, either directly or as a result of a criminal conviction.

I know that there has been concern expressed by members of the Australian Federal Police that they could be unduly or hastily dealt with under this legislation, but the opposition has looked at those concerns and believes that there are balances in the bill and remedies that officers can take if they believe they have been wrongly dismissed.

I think the bill is fair in the current climate, and the second reading speech of the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Jull), who is at the table, highlights it. The intention is to give the commissioner a broader and more effective power to end an appointment where the commissioner has lost confidence in a person's suitability for continued employment in the Australian Federal Police. The amendment will, in particular, permit the commissioner to act quickly and decisively to end the appointment of a person where the commissioner believes, on reasonable grounds, that there has been corruption, serious abuse of power or serious dereliction of duty.

The minister went on to say that, as the bill will widen the scope of the commissioner's powers to end appointments, the government believes it is also reasonable to extend to members and staff members additional remedies against the possibility that the commissioner's power might be exercised unfairly or unreasonably. Then it goes on to detail what those additional remedies are. The opposition's view is that there is some balance in this bill, and it is appropriate that the commissioner have these powers.

Mr Deputy Speaker, there is no need for me to take up my allotted time. Our view, as an opposition, is that we welcome the bill that is before the Committee. I think it is fair to say that the former Minister for Justice, Mr Duncan Kerr, can rightly take credit for a lot of the initiatives in this bill. I think he should be afforded due recognition. I know that he does welcome this bill before the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur, Stewart, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, in relation to the Australian Federal Police Amendment Bill, it has been said that Australians are becoming increasingly cynical about the society in which they live. Evidence suggests that Australians are less community minded than they were in the past, that they trust one another less and that they put less faith in traditional institutions. The family, the church, the media, the state and federal parliaments and even the judiciary have all, arguably, seen a deterioration in their public image in recent years. Likewise, the police force has experienced its share of criticism and has withstood numerous accusations ranging from racism to corruption.

SPEECH.PARA: Bodies such as the Fitzgerald inquiry in Queensland and the current Wood royal commission in New South Wales have partially eroded public confidence in our systems of law enforcement. This comes at a time when law and order rates highly on the list of community concerns. As the shadow minister at the table would fully understand, in recent election campaigns, at both state and federal levels, law and order issues have rated very highly on the political agenda. There is a widespread fear that the criminal justice system fails to punish serious crime effectively. There is also an understanding out there that criminals receive light sentences and the streets are no longer safe, as they were. That is the perception that members of the public have.

Confidence in law enforcement is ultimately the difference between a civil and peaceful society and complete lawlessness. For this reason, the confidence of the Australian people in the integrity of their police force is of vital importance. It behoves the elected representatives of the Australian people to support, defend and express their confidence in the police force. I put on the public record my support for that view. Members of parliament, both state and federal, should be seen to be supporting the police force in its operation and, I think, in both a moral and a personal way, should help the police to enforce the laws that are created by these parliaments.

This, of course, includes ensuring that the police force remains corruption free and that it has the ability to quickly respond to any suggestion of corruption or serious misconduct. This bill is aimed at avoiding a culture of corruption and misconduct in the Australian Federal Police. While the Wood royal commission in New South Wales has uncovered disturbing allegations of corruption in that state's police force, present and former members of the Australian Federal Police have also been implicated and named before the commission.

Against that backdrop, this bill empowers the Australian Federal Police Commissioner to dismiss police officers in cases of corruption or serious misconduct. Until now, there has been some doubt as to whether an officer of the Australian Federal Police could be sacked, even if they had been found guilty of a criminal charge. The officer would need to resign voluntarily or face disciplinary hearings, but the ability of the Australian Federal Police to move swiftly and effectively was compromised. This is an attitude of the public sector, and this bill really brings about quite a dramatic change to that attitude. Now the commissioner will be able to deal with any suggestion of wrongdoing in the Australian Federal Police and restore public confidence with decisive action.

The bill will provide some limited access to the unfair dismissal provisions of the Industrial Relations Act, except in cases of corruption, serious abuse of power or serious dereliction of duty. While protection from unfair dismissal may be fair enough for most employees, clearly there must be a different set of rules for the police force. The community demands that swift action be available to dismiss police officers with a proven tainted record.

Can you imagine what would happen if the former Labor government's unfair dismissal laws applied to the police force? In the case of these unfair dismissal laws, we have seen cases where workers have stolen, lied, accessed confidential files for personal use and been abusive to clients and seriously disloyal to the employer, and the Industrial Relations Court has reinstated them with back pay and compensation.

As members of the former government would understand, the Howard government does not agree with this unfair dismissal procedure and is very unhappy with the consequences: it was about $7,000 for every dismissal. It was better, in most cases, for the employer to pay the money because that is what it would finally cost, no matter what the reality of the case was, because of the legality of the unfair dismissal arrangements.

The Australian Federal Police and the state police forces need to be well equipped to respond to any suggestion of serious misconduct with very swift action, and not have to put up with the unfair dismissal procedures. For minor allegations, the police officers will be protected by the unfair dismissal provisions in the new Industrial Relations Act, where it is appropriate.

BREAK.PARA: It is important, and the government would agree, that any termination of a police officer's employment by the police commissioner must be on reasonable grounds. Obviously, there is an area for debate about that, as always in terms of dismissal, but in terms of keeping the integrity of the force, be it federal or state, these provisions are sensible.

The Australian Federal Police is the principal law enforcement agency of the Commonwealth; it is the federal force in charge of policing breaches of the laws of the Commonwealth. Aside from investigations relating to offences against Commonwealth law, the Australian Federal Police provides a community policing role in the ACT. The headquarters are located in Canberra, with regional commands in states and territories. There are nearly 3,000 members of the force in 31 Australian offices and 15 overseas bureaus. There are also Australian Federal Police representatives attached to Interpol headquarters. Members of the force have been involved in the UN peacekeeping operations in Cyprus, Mozambique, Cambodia and Somalia. The operations of some aspects of the Australian Federal Police are quite extensive.

The operational priorities of the Australian Federal Police are to provide the best in prevention, detection and investigation of criminal offences against the Commonwealth, with particular emphasis on organised crime and strategic intelligence, and to provide leadership in the Australian law enforcement effort. The federal police has cooperative relationships with the National Crime Authority, the Commonwealth Law Enforcement Board and state police agencies.

As an aside, it has always been my view that this cooperation between the Australian police force and the state police agencies is an important aspect. Most Australian citizens really deal on a day‐to‐day basis with state police agencies, whereas the federal jurisdiction in terms of its moral influence and its enforcement is somewhat removed from the day‐to‐day operations of the average citizen.

There have been previous reforms of the Australian police force structure aimed at stamping out corruption, which is certainly grabbing the headlines both in New South Wales and Victoria. In 1989, the parliament legislated to replace tenure for Australian Federal Police officers with a series of fixed appointments which, it seems to me, would be a step in the right direction. The commissioner was also given limited ability to end appointments for misconduct. The legislation builds further on that reform by strengthening the hand of the commissioner to dismiss police officers in such troublesome circumstances.

In February this year, the then Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) announced the completion of an enterprise agreement with the Australian Federal Police Association. I totally support that approach, in line with our industrial relations legislation, and I am pleased that the former minister was able to complete that enterprise agreement. Part of that package was a six per cent increase in salary, an increase in part‐time and job‐sharing work, working from home and other flexible working arrangements. Again, this is very compatible with the new industrial relations workplace bill that the Howard government has introduced into the House of Representatives and is now debating in that chamber.

According to the press release, the number of jobs performing routine or processing functions will be reduced and the emphasis will be on multiskilled, flexible units. Pay will be based on responsibilities of roles rather than a rank-based system. Again, this is compatible with the philosophy of the Howard government's industrial relations approach based on ability and merit rather than on an award and rank system, as it would be in the Federal Police. So there is a more productive and flexible arrangement of workplace arrangements by the Federal Police compatible with the general thrust of the government's industrial relations bill before the House.

Additional measures are agreed to in order to combat potential corruption. The press release is suggesting that there is a greater risk of corruption where some of the Australian Federal Police are isolated in longstanding squads or task forces in remote areas, or handling particular tasks. The federal police have recognised this and are moving away from static squads of the past to a more flexible system.

We think these reforms are timely not only in terms of the context of the debates here in the parliament but also in terms of debates on the police forces around Australia. This is a step in the right direction. Unfortunately, the Federal Police have been involved in some of the arguments and debates in the Wood royal commission in New South Wales.

In September last year, the commission heard that an elite joint task force consisting of Australian Federal Police members and New South Wales Drug Squad detectives had allegedly stolen $200,000 worth of drug money after an operation in 1983. The money had been seized as part of a raid but never submitted as evidence. Allegedly, it was split amongst the members of the joint task force. The Canberra Times of 27 September 1995 reported that one of the secret witnesses told the commission that he had seen a psychiatrist and was suffering moral collapse after accepting $10,000 which had been stolen from the drug traffickers. Allegedly, the witness had found an envelope stuffed with $20 and $50 notes in his drawer at the joint task force headquarters at Kings Cross. After leaving it in his drawer for a number of days, he eventually took the money home and hid it in his sports bag. He reported that he was suffering moral tensions and a festering sore in his subconscious ever since he had been involved in part of that corruption. Unfortunately, in this case, the Federal Police officers were caught in an isolated situation of corruption stemming from the joint operation with the New South Wales police force. This took place some time ago but it does add to the public perception and concern about the general performance of police forces around Australia.

I will conclude by reiterating my belief that members of all parliaments should try to support members of the police force. They, like members of the parliament, are public persons and often many of the middle‐of‐the‐road police officers are wrongly accused of being part of the total so‐called corruption of some of the forces. My own exposure in Victoria suggests that the police force in that state is fairly good. Chief Commissioner Comrie has taken every effort to enforce the law, as the law‐makers have put it forward in the parliaments, in a day‐to‐day operation to ensure that crime is kept to a minimum. It is a difficult task. I have heard Commissioner Comrie give some private remarks about the operation of the police force.

I observe that certain media outlets emphasise the deficiencies of the police force and give undue coverage of that, compared to other elements of the society who enjoy certain notoriety about activities relating to police shootings and activities related to civil liberties groups. I draw the attention of the parliament to the disparity in some of these public arguments between the position of the Victorian police force and what the chief commissioner might have to say, as compared to what some civil liberty groups might put forward as their position.

I think the Victorian police force, which as a Victorian I have some day‐to‐day contact with, has done a pretty good job. The police officers that I have dealt with are conscientious. They conduct themselves in a civil manner, executing the laws in terms of traffic offences and in terms of—

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the way they treated the Premier.

—I noticed that particular report this morning. But my experience has been that they do their best to keep law and order throughout most areas in Victoria. It is a difficult task and I place on record that, overall, I think the Victorian police force does a good job.

BREAK.PARA: However, in relation to the Federal Police force, which we are talking about, this bill brings about a change of attitude—that if they do not do the right thing the chief commissioner has the capacity to make a change dramatically in removing personnel. That will help with the general perception that the chief commissioner can move and make the changes if he so wishes. I concede that there are a couple of downsides, based on the fact that he may move peremptorily. But, on balance, I think the chief commissioner needs this power.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to make a couple of comments. I indicated earlier that I was going to move to have the matter referred to the main chamber and I have considered that in more detail. I was interested in the comments made by the minister at the table. I think he was perhaps not being serious when he suggested that impeding the bill's progress through the Main Committee was somehow going to impede its progress as a piece of legislation through the parliamentary process, which is obviously not true.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the bill and I support the bill's intentions. I just make the comment that the bill was introduced into the Senate. One of the reasons for that is that the Senate has a standing order that requires bills originating in the House to be presented by 30 May in order for them to be considered by the Senate within a particular time frame. One of the consequences of the relatively late start of this new parliament has been that bills which must desperately be passed—and I consider this to be one of them—have to be introduced in the Senate. Otherwise they will end up in the Senate backlog of legislation and not be dealt with for some time.

If I can just paraphrase the words of Winston Churchill, it is probably fair to say, in relation to police and the criminal justice system, that Australia's criminal justice system is probably the worst in the world, apart from all the others. I make that comment in view of the fact that, of all the police and criminal justice models around the world, the Australian one does have some particularly strong advantages. Of course, it has disadvantages, and disadvantages are highlighted in this particular bill.

I commend the work of a colleague, the former independent member for the South Coast, John Hatton, who served for some considerable time in the New South Wales parliament. He pursued the issue of police corruption in New South Wales almost incessantly, to the extent that he was able to cause to be initiated a royal commission into the New South Wales police force. He pursued that against the backdrop of considerable criticism from both sides of politics. In the last phase of his career in the New South Wales parliament, he was given a pretty hard time and was considered by some to be almost obsessive in his pursuit of that particular objective. If anybody is a hero of modern times in relation to our criminal justice system, then John Hatton, the former independent member for the South Coast, is one of them.

A police force, more often than not, reflects the society which it serves; another truism that is reflected in the bill. We face considerable difficulties in our community at present with behaviour—that is, what is considered to be acceptable behaviour in relation to what is considered to be, let us say, a fair return for one's effort. The whole of the service of police force members around the country has to be taken into consideration against that backdrop. In other words, you get the police force you deserve. We must, as a community, ensure that our police forces around the country are operating to the highest possible standards. However, in parts of the country, there are serious concerns and, unfortunately, as the member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) has indicated, those concerns reflect on every member of the police force. That is an extraordinary imposition on the men and women who diligently serve their communities as police officers.

We have a community that every night of the week watches television programs with police themes: cop dramas. The community is fed a perception about police behaviour and police techniques that is often wildly different from the reality of day‐to‐day policing. One of my favourite programs is The Bill. It is probably the police drama that most closely reflects actual police work. That is because it looks at the day‐to‐day operation of a police station and, of course, the interaction of police officers as a consequence. More recent Australian dramas such as Blue Heelers have, I think, given a much greater and more realistic, sometimes gritty, feel to the reality of day‐to‐day policing in a modern Australian society. Some of the shows that were on television when I first arrived in this country, including Homicide and Division 4, were romanticised to a large extent, probably reflecting the romantic view that people had of the police forces. After all, a police force, as I mentioned, reflects the community. As communities develop, there is a pressure on police forces to develop as a consequence.

It is clear from the Wood royal commission that, in the case of the Australian Federal Police and, of course, the New South Wales police, there are significant problems with corruption. There have been significant allegations and compelling evidence, I would have thought, of corruption. Quite clearly, it requires a sensible resolution and this bill provides that, particularly in relation to the role of the commissioner of police as the chief executive officer of a modern police force.

When I first joined the police force in Western Australia, the commissioner was probably second only to the Premier in terms of the perception of the role as a significant public official. I certainly remember, when I first joined, that the commissioner was seen in a sort of revered way, up on the horizon, somebody of considerable authority. That authority, when I was a junior policeman, was very strong in the force. In fact, the commissioner had quite extraordinary powers to dismiss police officers whom he or his advisers considered to be unsuitable to remain in the force. It is obvious that, if you have a situation where human beings are police officers, you are going to get human problems.

I spoke earlier about the insidious problem of drug importation and drug trafficking in our community. The problem is probably compounded by the extraordinary and enormous rewards that can be achieved by those who participate in that sort of criminal behaviour. You have a situation wherein the police forces are rubbing up against this sort of corrupt, criminal, conspiratorial behaviour. They see the rewards. The problem is that in some instances, as we have clearly seen in the Wood royal commission, the temptation is overpowering. It is clear that we have to deal with this, as a community, in a way that properly reflects the reality of the situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Reform the drug laws.

—The member makes a comment about the reform of drug laws. There is some scope for the reform of certain drug laws. But, in the final analysis, if there is a profit it does not matter what sort of drug it is; whether it is marijuana, an amphetamine or one of the latest chemical drugs. It does not matter what they are; where there is a criminal profit to be gained, you are going to have people attracted into participating.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen people who were even prepared to risk their lives to bring back drugs from South‐East Asia, knowing that they were facing the possibility of a death sentence. They are

BREAK.PARA: so significantly attracted towards the profit, through their own drug addiction or just through sheer greed, that they are prepared to risk their lives—and, in many cases, risk 30 years in some of the worst prison conditions in the world—in order to either make that profit or feed their own drug needs.

It is clear that, in modern policing and the reform of modern policing, there is a need for greater visibility and scrutiny. If that requires the sort of authority that this bill provides the commissioner of the Australian Federal Police with, then that is absolutely necessary. In some ways, it probably reflects some of the past standing of commissioners of police as being people with considerable authority in directing the day‐to‐day operations of their forces.

The independence of the police force is a very important facet of the balances within our criminal justice system. In more recent times, some of this independence has been imposed upon. I believe that is to the detriment of a better and more responsive, efficient and decent police force effort around the country. In particular, in the case of the Australian Federal Police, the role of the commissioner is absolutely critical. The commissioner's role should be as independent as is possible within the relationship between the commissioner's office, the minister and the parliament to whom the minister is responsible.

In the case of rewards, one of the areas that I have wanted to see changed and enhanced is that of the remuneration and benefits that are available to police officers in our day‐to‐day community. After all, when police officers are well paid, in relative terms, compared to other members of the community, and they are secure in their employment in terms of doing the right thing, getting the job done properly and being decent and honest members of the force, obviously that is a greater deterrent to succumbing to the attractions of criminal profits or becoming involved in conspiracies with organised crime or other criminals.

That is something that we all have to look at. If we want to have police forces that are going to be impeccable, efficient, responsive and answerable to the community, we ought to make sure that not only are we getting the best possible personnel into those forces but also they are well renumerated for their work, so that they are seen within the community as being higher than perhaps they have been in the past.

Over the last 20 to 30 years, the standing of police officers in the community was reduced steadily until they became, in many cases, the butt of abuse. To refer to my own particular experience, I can recollect that, when I first joined the job, in social terms a police officer was almost seen as a pariah. If you turned up to a social gathering, it was almost as though you had suddenly put the pall of doom over it. Of course, people started whispering in corners—

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps they were using all those drugs!

—That is an interesting observation; perhaps the member could expand on that, at a later stage, from his own personal observations. I agree that it is a question of perception and myth. We took on the British police model as our role model in the formation of our Australian police forces. We adopted, changed and developed that within the Australian context, both in the states and nationally, with the Australian Federal Police acting as the federal police force.

BREAK.PARA: Amongst those things that we took on, as opposed to other police jurisdictions around the world, was the concept that a police officer should be a part of the community, interact with the community and live in the community, as opposed to the barrack style police forces on the mainland of Europe and elsewhere. I must say that I think that is one of the great advantages. Community`visibility is absolutely critical. One of the things that is occurring in some police jurisdictions is the bringing of detectives back into uniform so that they are visible going about their duties. It is something that in the past I have opposed but, in the light of some of the circumstances of recent times, I think it helps the visibility of police practices and helps the community and the police to interact to ensure that they have very high standards.

The other aspect is the scrutiny of the courts. I have to commend the former Minister for Justice, the member for Denison (Mr Kerr), on this issue. Some years back, when he first introduced the requirement for Australian Federal Police officers to videotape interviews, I was a critic of his. I thought that at times, particularly in remote areas of Australia, videotaping would pose significant problems of access, facilities, distance and time involved after apprehending a suspect, interviewing, and going through the further processes that are applicable under the relevant statutes.

This, I believe, has now proved to be a significant advantage. It has enhanced police work. It has also meant, in the context of prosecution of cases in the courts, that the courts are able to see the accused at the point when they are being interviewed by the police in a way that often reveals more about them than mountains and mountains of written or oral evidence could possibly do. I would say from my discussions with other police officers, particularly the ones I consider to be thoughtful about these processes, that I believe that they are all in agreement with the changes that have been brought in, in particular the changes relating to videotaping of interviews. Also, videotaping is a critical part of the element of visibility, which I mentioned earlier. It means that people can see the process, with the benefit of hindsight to a certain extent. It is there on the record in physical evidence, visual and in sound. That is something that permits the courts to have a greater scrutiny of police practices and police behaviour.

I reiterate some of the comments made earlier in relation to cuts. But, if we are going to have a police force and an Australian Federal Police that is going to be effective, it has to be as independent as possible. In other words, within the communal justice system it must be able to exercise its statutory responsibilities in a way that is consistent with the basic principles of a proper, responsive criminal justice system. Also, it is not to be interlinked or merged in joint standing facilities with other agencies. That is something I have criticised in the past; it is something from the former Minister for Justice that I have criticised. I felt that the joint standing operations between the NCA and the Australian Federal Police were to the detriment of both organisations. I believe that each should be self‐standing and clearly separated so that they are clearly answerable in their own ways to their own particular statutes and, at the end of the day, via the minister, to the parliament.

Our processes are critical to a criminal justice system. It is fair to say that in the past, particularly in New South Wales, if the legislators had been more diligent in looking over the operations of the New South Wales Police, we would have had a different situation. There were all sorts of allegations in the 1950s, the 1960s, the 1970s and the 1980s in relation to the interlinking of corrupt behaviour in the police and some of the political figures of the times. But it is fair that we must ensure that the police force's activities, its responsiveness, its efficiency, its effects, and its method of operations are as clearly visible as possible so that the community can see, to their satisfaction or otherwise, that they are getting a service that they deserve.

I said at the beginning that you get the police force you deserve. If we have got police forces that are less than satisfactory, we have to look back at our own community and we have to make the decision to reform the police forces in ways that are consistent with what we ask the community to do themselves. After all, police officers are human beings. A vast majority of them around the country perform their duties honestly and decently, as best they can. In many cases, as we saw recently with the Port Arthur massacre and in other instances, they go far beyond the call of duty to provide services that many other citizens would probably find themselves completely unable to do.

We ask them to do that on our behalf. In order to ensure that they have the standing in the community, we have got to ensure that they are able to work in the sorts of administrative and organisational settings that enhance their honesty and their commitment to their work, and at the end of the day give the public the satisfaction that it is getting the best possible police service that it deserves.

I commend this bill to the Main Committee. As I mentioned earlier, it is important that this bill is passed as soon as possible. As a consequence I have refrained from referring it back to the main chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull, David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank members who have contributed to the debate on this legislation this morning. I particularly thank the members of the opposition for their support. I would also like to thank the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) for not proceeding with his motion regarding this bill. I trust that the bill will now have a speedy passage in its remaining stages.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 May, on motion by Mr Sharp:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tanner, Lindsay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Civil Aviation Amendment Bill 1996 is designed to increase the size of the board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority by two: the present number of four lay members will be increased to six. The authority's Chief Executive Officer, Mr Leroy Keith, is also an ex officio member of the board. The bill is also designed to empower the minister to appoint one of the members of the board as a deputy chair of the board.

SPEECH.PARA: Briefly, the background to this legislation has to be seen in the context of the tragic disaster of the Monarch Airlines crash at Young in mid‐1993 and the subsequent Bureau of Air Safety Investigation report into that crash. That led to the then Minister for Transport, Mr Laurie Brereton, announcing that the government intended to separate the commercial and safety regulatory functions of the former Civil Aviation Authority into two separate bodies. The legislation to do so was announced by the then minister on 28 March 1995 and was passed by the parliament a couple of months later. As a result of that legislation, two separate bodies—Airservices Australia and the Civil Aviation Safety Authority—were created by the parliament.

The controversy which surrounded the previous Civil Aviation Authority has not died as a result of that decision. Still very much a live issue in debate, particularly within the aviation sector, are the questions associated with the safety regulatory functions performed by the Civil Aviation Safety Authority as it now is.

The new board of the authority took office on 1 July 1995. The four lay members who were appointed then and who are still in office are: the chair of the board, Mr Justice Bill Fisher, who is Chief Judge of the New South Wales Industrial Court as well; Ms Gaby Hollows, who is a consumer advocate; Dr Claire Pollock, who is a systems safety expert; and Mr Geoff Molloy, who is a former Qantas pilot. As I indicated, the director, Mr Leroy Keith, is an ex officio member of the board.

Shortly after coming to office, the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, Mr Sharp, endeavoured to force the four members of the board to resign. He wrote letters to them individually seeking their resignations. He rang each of them individually seeking their resignations and at at least one meeting, and possibly more, collectively spoke to the board members asking them to resign.

The only reason that he gave at that point was, and I quote, `That I have obligations to other people.' Given that the board members had been in office for only about nine months, that there had been no substantive complaints levelled against them, and that the issues which arose from, for example, the BASI investigation into the Monarch disaster, predated their period on the board, it was rather a peculiar performance by the minister. In fact, he subsequently admitted that it would not go down as one of his best performances.

He did point out, correctly, that the coalition policy prior to the election was to increase the amount of aviation expertise, or direct aviation industry background, represented on the board. This was a position that was strongly supported by the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association, which strongly supported the coalition, and Mr Sharp in particular, during the election campaign. AOPA is headed by Mr Dick Smith and Mr Boyd Munro who is present here in the gallery today. It is fair to say that AOPA has been in substantial conflict with the former CAA and now its successor, CASA, over a wide range of safety regulation issues. A number of those issues have already been canvassed or dealt with by the minister.

This bill has emerged ultimately because of the minister's failure to shift the existing board members. It is very disturbing that in presenting his ministerial statement to the parliament yesterday the minister made completely unsubstantiated statements to the effect that the existing board members were, `putting their own interests ahead of aviation safety.' These are fairly strong things to say about people who are performing a community function by representing the people of this country as board members on the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. It is a pretty strong accusation to make, without any substantial evidence to back it up, accusing them of putting their own self‐interests ahead of the interests of aviation safety in this country. It is something that I think the minister may well regret in the future when he reflects on it.

The opposition does not object to the content of the bill. It does not see a huge difference between four and six members of the board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. If you look at the range of memberships of various equivalent boards, you will see that the numbers vary quite a bit, that there is no golden or perfect number, and that both four and six members are equally acceptable. So the notion of increasing the size of the board does not attract any criticism from the opposition; it does not see that there is any optimum number for members of the board.

BREAK.PARA: Equally, the opposition does not object to the notion that the two additional places should be used to place additional expertise or aviation industry background on the board. The opposition believes that such boards should have a balance between generalist expertise, such as that of some of the existing members of the board, and specialist expertise that is directly relevant to the area that is being regulated.

A number of very interesting statements have been made by the minister on this issue. I think it is important to take a more sober view of the issue. For example, as I cited in the House yesterday, I doubt whether there are too many directors of BHP who grew up shovelling coal into steel furnaces or working as ironworkers. I note also, as I did yesterday, that the new head of the transport department, Dr Hawke, is in fact a geneticist by trade. I think it was an excellent appointment and it illustrates that there are many positions in the hierarchy in the public sector that should have a generalist rather than a direct specialist involved in the area.

In the case of the CASA board, I believe there should be a mix: some aviation specialists and some generalists. It is also important to mention, as the minister as failed to do, that one of the three members he says has no expertise in aviation does, in fact, have very directly relevant expertise in system safety, and that is Dr Claire Pollock. She studied under Professor James Reason, who has developed the methodology which is most widely acknowledged as the appropriate methodology for analysing disasters such as major airline crashes and who, I understand, headed the investigation into the Manchester plane disaster some years ago. So it is quite clear that one of those three does have directly relevant expertise.

Given that the function of the CASA board is not to go out and inspect the planes or do the hands‐on work of the authority—which, quite appropriately, should be done by people with the directly relevant expertise—the function of the board is to ensure that the authority fulfils its obligations under the act of parliament which governs it. That is something which, I would have thought, a judge would be fairly well qualified to do, being somebody with substantial legal expertise. That supervisory role of the board, in a general sense, is quite different from the function of actually performing the task of safety regulation and administration that the authority itself does.

On the substance of the legislation, the opposition does not object to the notion of the appointment of one of the board members as the deputy chair. From time to time, having a deputy chair will be of some consequence. A quick examination of similar boards, such as that of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority, indicates that most similar boards under the Commonwealth umbrella have a position of deputy chair.

There is some controversy with respect to the prospect that the minister is endeavouring to create a position on the board for Dick Smith and, in doing so, to force out the existing board members by backdoor means because he is unable to do so by the front door. The second reading amendment which I hereby move is specifically designed to deal not only with that situation but also with the broader concern that the opposition has with respect to people who have a partisan position in the aviation industry being appointed to the board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority.

The opposition does not have any objection to Dick Smith as an individual. In fact, I have not met Mr Smith, although I have had several discussions with Mr Munro of the same organisation. So far, the indications are that I would probably agree with Mr Smith and Mr Munro on one or two issues. I certainly disagree with them on a number of others. The fact is, regardless of Mr Smith's position on any of these issues and whether he is right or wrong, he is a very high profile and quite controversial campaigner within the aviation industry, campaigning on issues that directly relate to CASA's jurisdiction.

In my view—regardless of whether I agree 100 per cent, or disagree 100 per cent, with him on those issues—it is inappropriate for anybody who plays or has recently played such a role to be appointed to the CASA board. Somebody who has been a highly partisan political lobbyist representing a section of the industry—regardless of who that might be—should not be appointed to what is basically an umpire's position. It is perfectly reasonable to have people with a background and expertise in the industry, as I indicated before, and I think Mr Molloy is a good example of that. But I and the opposition do not believe that it is appropriate for people who have been strong campaigners and political lobbyists on issues related to CASA's jurisdiction to be placed on the board.

CASA makes very difficult decisions and choices that affect people's lives and livelihoods. It would be inappropriate to have people on the board of CASA who have axes to grind. There is a serious risk that, if that occurs, the CASA board will turn into a battleground between competing interests in the aviation industry. This is another reason why it is appropriate to have at least some people on the board who do not come from the aviation industry itself, but have other relevant expertise. In summary, the opposition opposes any partisan advocate for any particular section of the aviation industry being represented directly on the CASA board.

I should also make it clear that the opposition does not agree with the general position that Mr Smith has been associated with on what is termed `affordable safety'. I will not repeat them today, but I will note the comments made—at pages 8, 50, 73 and 75—by the coroner who investigated the Monarch crash, with respect to the `affordable safety' philosophy and the impact that that had on the Civil Aviation Authority, as it then was.

It is too early for me, as shadow minister for transport, to form conclusive views on the issue of to what extent the problems of the then Civil Aviation Authority were caused by that philosophy. In fact, it may be very difficult to form conclusive views at all, because these things are extremely complex. Certainly, the coroner's view was that that philosophy had a significant contributing impact on the Monarch crash, and I think we have to take some note of that.

It is interesting that there is an inherent contradiction in the position of the minister on these issues. On one hand, he has been very strongly supportive of the agenda that Mr Smith and his organisation have put—for example, the overruling of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority on the question of electronic locater transmitters. So far, he has appeared to be very supportive, and that will be clearly evidenced if he does appoint Mr Smith to the board. On the other hand, he has taken a very strong and very vigorous position, particularly in opposition, with respect to the performance of the Civil Aviation Authority and then CASA, regarding rigorous safety enforcement. I would suggest to him that there is an inherent contradiction in those two points of view and that, at some point, that contradiction will hit home.

I turn now very briefly in conclusion to the amendment that I gather has been circulated by the honourable member for Calare (Mr Andren). This is at least the third such one, I think I am correct in saying. One was from the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), but they are all on the same issue; that is, giving the minister the capacity to dismiss the existing members of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority board. This particular amendment in effect gives the minister unrestricted power to dismiss the members of the board at any time, for no reason. The existing legislation specifies reasons, such as becoming of unsound mind or bankruptcy and the like, which are usually included for dismissal of members of boards of statutory authorities.

The amendment that has been moved by the member for Calare in effect would allow the minister unfettered power to dismiss board members. The opposition does not support this amendment; firstly, because it is directly targeted at removing existing board members where, as far as the opposition can see, there is no justification for doing so, since they have not done anything wrong in the discharge of their duties; and, secondly, particularly when the minister is pursuing another avenue which allows him to influence the composition of the board by adding two members. The opposition believes that this is completely unjustified in the specific circumstances.

More importantly, there is a broader principle here, and that is the whole question of the relationship between statutory authorities and the government. If you have a situation where the minister can arbitrarily dismiss board members—all of them, at any time, and for no reason—you have to question why you have a statutory authority in the first place and why, in this case, you do not simply return to the old department of transport situation where the conduct of civil aviation safety regulation is directly under ministerial control; because the net effect of having board members who are subject to instant dismissal is the same.

If you apply this principle across the board to other statutory authorities, and if you do it here, you have to ask why you are not doing it elsewhere. If you apply it across the board, then you effectively negate one of the key components of the whole concept of a statutory authority which is, to some extent, to depoliticise the process that it is involved with and the obligations that it is there to discharge; to remove the political process a bit from that, without severing ultimate lines of accountability but still allowing the proper administration of that area to occur without direct day‐to‐day political interference. That is the whole purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I will allow the honourable member to refer to the anticipated amendment, but it is drawing a long bow to go into the detail, so I would ask him to come back to the matter being debated. I do not mind him referring to the amendment, but it is a bit beyond the pale to go into the details of it at this stage.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. That is pretty much all I wish to say with respect to the amendment. For the reasons associated with both the specific situation in this instance and the general principle of the damage that it would do to the structure of statutory authorities and their relationship with the government, the opposition will oppose the amendment.

BREAK.PARA: My final comments relate to the way the minister is dealing with the question of the current performance of the staff of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. It seems pretty clear that the staff of the former Civil Aviation Authority, several years ago, were derelict in their duty in a number of cases. You only have to read the coroner's report into the Monarch crash to see that that fairly clearly was the case. However, the minister has made a number of fairly flamboyant and rather reckless statements in recent times suggesting that this sort of conduct is continuing, that the same people are doing the same things. For example, in his statement yesterday, he said that he was concerned that the old culture still existed `despite the change of name', that existing CAA officers felt `somehow immune to the consequences of their own wrongdoing', and that the government would not be `repeating the errors of the previous government in allowing that attitude to continue uncorrected.'

The disturbing conclusions that I have reached are twofold. First, continuing accusations are being levelled against existing officers, without people being named and without direct action being taken in any way against the individual officers. All of the officers are slurred as a result of that. Second, no evidence of existing contemporary failure, of the type which has been revealed to have occurred in 1993‐94, has been put forward. That is the first concern.

Second, there is no evidence that the minister is actually doing anything about this. If he believes that there are officers in CASA who are derelict in their duty, then he should be doing something about it. I doubt that expanding the board by two, even on the most optimistic view, will be a mechanism for doing something about that problem, if it does exist. All he said on that front was that he would be pursuing these matters with the director. I think he owes the parliament, the people of Australia, the people in the industry, and particularly the people in the authority, some more detailed explanation as to precisely what he believes is wrong here and now, who the people involved are and what he proposes to do about it.

It is very worrying that the minister continues to act as if he is the shadow minister. It is particularly worrying for the general reputation of safety regulation in this country that he is still undermining the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, still attacking it, when he is now the person responsible for it. He is no longer the shadow minister; he is the person responsible for the organisation. He needs to be a lot more careful in his statements and how he deals with these issues in the public arena, because he is now the minister. Unfortunately, I think he has yet to come to grips with that.

The opposition, as I indicated, does not oppose the bill, subject to the second reading amendment which I will move and which opposes the amendment which will be moved by the member for Calare (Mr Andren). I move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that:

(1) it is appropriate that the Board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority should include members in areas such as the law, regulation and general systems safety, as well as members with specific expertise in aviation; and

(2) no person should be appointed to the Board who has engaged recently in political lobbying or public advocacy on aviation safety issues on behalf of any company or interest group involved in the aviation industry".

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter, Bob, Jnr, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not too sure now whether I am speaking to the amendment moved by the ALP or whether I am speaking to the bill itself.
—You are speaking to both.

—Thank you. I have come along to speak to the civil aviation bill, and to the amendment, because the biggest population centre in Kennedy is Mount Isa, and Mount Isa is a good example of what is happening in civil aviation in Australia. The economic rationalist government of the last 13 years, Mr Keating's government, introduced very doctrinaire, economic rationalist policies. It is interesting to hear the other side of the House refer to ideology. They have been the party driven by ideology and their ideology, amusingly for me, is inimical to the interests of the average working person whom they purport to represent.

SPEECH.PARA: Civil aviation in Australia provides a good example of what is occurring. If you take the user‐pays principle and you apply it to the field of aviation, what happens is that Brisbane gets a $300 million airport—or $600 million, depending upon which newspaper report you want to read—which services overseas people or people who want to leave Australia and go overseas. They get a $300 million international terminal which would arguably be one of the more beautiful buildings, outside of our cathedrals, in Australia.

Under this same principle, what happens in Mount Isa? Mount Isa is a town of 20,000 people that produces $1,500 million worth of export earnings for Australia every single year. What happens to the 20,000 of us—brave little souls that we are—who live out in this area? What happens in Mount Isa under the policies of the previous government? And I must say, in all fairness, that there are people on our side who adhere to the same sorts of policies of economic rationalism. So what I am attacking here is not so much the ALP but the economic rationalists.

Mount Isa, as I said, is producing $1,500 million of export earnings for Australia, with men risking their lives going into the depths of the earth daily in very hard conditions. I worked as a labourer there myself for a small but significant proportion of my life. It is hard work and it is dangerous work. To give just one example, every one of the people on my gang at the lead smelter at Mount Isa Mines had a lead count, with the exception of me.

TALK.START.PARA: —You jest about it, but if I were in the ALP I would not be laughing at miners who suffer from disease incurred in their employment. I would not be cracking jokes about that issue. Mr Maitland will not be pleased when I speak to him. I have to take up the interjection from the honourable opposition spokesman who laughed at me when I said that six of the seven people in the gang that I worked with at Mount Isa Mines had a lead count. That is not a laughing matter. He should not only apologise to those men, but he should apologise to the House as well.
—Order! I ask the honourable member to address the chair and to be conscious that interjections do not need to be answered.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take your very wise advice. I have made the point. Let them suffer as a result of it. They have been foolish and callous enough to interject in that manner, so they can suffer the consequences of their machine‐gun mouths.

SPEECH.PARA: In Mount Isa there were 68 employees at the local airport. A number of them were employed on the fire brigade tender there. A number were employed in the control tower and a number were employed in maintenance to keep the airstrip in good working order. The terminal staff who keep the terminal clean and in good working order are still there and do an excellent job. All of the other people are gone. Where we had 68 employees at the Mount Isa airport, we now have two employees and one contractor.

So if you are landing in Mount Isa, just hope and pray that nothing goes wrong because the nearest fire brigade tender is some 10 kilometres away, in the centre of the city. It might be more than 10 kilometres—I do not know how far it is. But it is a long way away. So if something goes wrong, say your prayers.
