In Mount Isa you just suffer, while people who are rich and want to go overseas have the magnificent $300 million terminal to enjoy. Overseas tourists are provided with that $300 million terminal. But the workers in Mount Isa who might want to go and visit their relatives on the coast, or who might have to go away for an operation or for treatment for lead poisoning, which was laughed at by the opposition people here—

TALK.START.PARA: —Wrong!

—They do not have any of the services enjoyed by the big city airports in Australia. That is what economic rationalism is all about. If you have not got the numbers, you get nothing; if you have got the numbers, you get everything. It is a `winner take all' situation. There is nothing at all for those who belong to minority groups and, by definition, people who live in a small centre outside a metropolitan city are a minority group.

SPEECH.PARA: I add that we have also lost our Qantas services to Mount Isa. This is partially due to the fringe benefits tax introduced by the ALP government that resulted in us having these pernicious fly‐ins and the change of policy by the state government. All the mining is now being done out of places such as Brisbane and Townsville. It is no longer being done on the ground and inland Australia is becoming a big empty shell.

That brings me to another aspect which is very important. One of my two offices is in Innisfail. If you head due west in an aeroplane from Innisfail for about 40 kilometres, the area is heavily populated. At about 40 or 50 kilometres from Innisfail, you cross the Great Dividing Range and there is nothing for the best part of 10,000 kilometres. There is no sign of human habitation when you look out either side of the aircraft. There might be an occasional water trough set up or an occasional fence line; it would be very doubtful that you would see any other sign of human habitation. You would have just flown over 60 per cent of Australia's arable land and 75 per cent of our water supply. Seventy‐five per cent of this nation's water supply is in that area of land.

There is no excuse for this nation to be sitting on that huge resource that the good Lord has given us as Australians: to have done nothing at all with this is immoral, a terrible disgrace and a reflection upon every single person in this country. It is an indefensible position. In the world's tribunals, such as the United Nations, it is an indefensible position, when tonight people in so much of the world are going to bed hungry.

Because that area is empty, it is very important to aviation: if an aircraft gets into trouble, it is in a lot of trouble. You are in the middle of nowhere. There are no airstrips and what airstrips there are are not marked on maps. One of the issues that I have marked down here to raise today is the total inadequacy of maps in Australia; they simply do not have the airstrips at station properties marked on them. Sometimes, where they are marked, they are marked with extreme inaccuracy. We had a station property in that area and we changed the position of the airstrip, but I think it would still be desirable for both airstrips to appear on the map.

Accurate maps would be a very important thing to us. Automatic landing lights cost money, but I think the government could deliver them more cheaply than individual shire councils deliver them at present. Homing beacons are enormously important. I could be corrected here, but I do not think any of the towns along the pathway from Innisfail west to the Indian Ocean have homing beacons or automatic lights, which at night‐time can make the difference between staying alive and not staying alive.

At a recent tribunal hearing, I had to submit my itineraries and I was quite amazed to find out that I was spending 43½ hours per week travelling. Thanks to the `one vote, one value' imposed on us by the parliament, I represent 85,000 people; most people here represent about 70,000 people.

I wish to heaven that we had one vote, one value. Because I represent this huge area, almost all of that 43½ hours travel is in light aircraft. Mr Deputy Speaker, on three occasions I have been in a light aircraft and we have lost a motor. We had very good pilots, we were very lucky, and we escaped from that situation. On another occasion there had been some bad navigation by a pilot. He was an experienced pilot, too, I might add. He missed where he should have been by nearly 150 kilometres. When you are starting to run low on fuel, when you have got absolutely no idea where you are and it is the middle of the night, it is a very dangerous situation. But, as luck would have it, we were close to a town, I was able to recognise what that town was, and we were able to find our way back again to civilisation.

But finding a little township, as we did on that occasion, is not very helpful. Landing in the main street at night would be extremely dangerous. But, if we had some system, or some device to switch on, whereby we knew where the airstrip was at these little towns, that would be of enormous benefit. In this case we were not close to a town where we could have switched on landing lights, but we were not far away. We were only about 40 kilometres away from a town where we could have switched on landing lights and found our way. But, at night, you have got nothing much that you can hold on to if you have not got the homing beacons.

There is another issue which is vitally important in the area of civil aviation. If you read the Australian constitution, you will find that aviation is one of the heads of power which is the responsibility of the federal government. All of the airstrips in the electorate of Kennedy—every single airport, with one exception, I think—are imposed upon the local authority. There is nothing in the constitution about local authorities running airports or aviation; but again we had the economic rationalists and a really vicious decision by the then federal government of Mr Hawke forcing these local authorities to take on these airstrips. The federal government said, `We are pulling out. We are not going to put a single cent into these airstrips forever. So it is upon your head.' I argued very strongly in the Queensland cabinet that the Queensland government ought to tell the federal government to go to hell and, if any accidents occurred, it would be upon the head of the federal government. The federal government has had the responsibility of looking after this area placed upon it by the people of Australia.

Some people may say, `With economic rationalism and user pays, if you cannot pay your way out there, do not live out there.' Mr Deputy Speaker, they have put that proposition to us, and the net result of it has been that people out there have said, `All right; we cannot live out here. We are moving.' Thirty‐nine per cent of people in western Queensland have moved over the last 25 years, and they are running away just about as fast as their feet can carry them, thanks to the user‐pays principle and the principles of the economic rationalists. But, unfortunately, they are taking with them the wealth of this nation. This nation's biggest export earning item in l988 was wool, as it was for the 10 years prior to that—or neck and neck with coal, as it has been for all of our history. Half of our sheep herd has gone, and the numbers are falling dramatically right at this very moment. The cattle herd—the fifth biggest export earning item for this nation—is falling over.

The difficulties placed upon the mining industry by the Native Title Act that has been legislated into existence by this place, and the enormous power given to the extreme element of the green movement in Australia, have dealt death blows to the mining industry as well. Because of the fringe benefits tax and because of the user‐pays principle, there are very many things now in these areas that we are doing without. Let me come back to Mount Isa for one brief moment, because they are discussing industrial relations in the other place. Because of the fringe benefits tax and because of the government's policy of having high interest rates and a high Australian dollar, Mount Isa Mines has suffered enormous pain. The net result of that is that we lost our fly‐ins. One of the great advantages of working in Mount Isa was having your annual free holiday to Brisbane. Even though many people would consider Mount Isa a hostile living environment, I would not. It is my home. I love it, of course, and I enjoy it out there. But most people would say that living there is very difficult. So, when they lost the annual holiday flights, there was very strong persuasion and pressure put upon the residents of Mount Isa to simply leave. The population of Mount Isa has dropped from 30,000 to 20,000.

Whether it is in the field of mining, which used to whip along at about six per cent growth per year and has now dropped down to about 0.6 per cent growth per year—most certainly under one per cent—or whether it is in the field of agriculture, which is down from about three per cent annual growth to about 0.2 per cent annual growth over the last four years, you can see that people are moving out. In real terms, these industries are declining.

The last time I looked, I found that 93 per cent of the nation's entire export earnings comes from these industries. But if you remove the services from these areas you will deal body blows to these industries. I could stand here all day and argue, if you want to go into true economic rationalism. If we really were fair dinkum about figuring out what was paying for itself and what was not, we would close down Sydney and move the population out to the Mount Isas, the Longreaches and the Hughendens. If you were being fair dinkum about economic rationalism obviously the only places where this country is internationally competitive is in those fields. Our export earnings indicate quite clearly that 93 per cent of our income comes from those areas.

I come here today with a great deal of bitterness. When I land in Mount Isa I know that—like all of my fellow citizens in an area where my own family have lived for over 100 years—we live in very great jeopardy. My grandaddy was one of the original 26 investors in Qantas. The reason they invested in Qantas was—and here I want to refer to Reverend Flynn who founded the Royal Flying Doctor Service—to bring a mantle of safety to the outback. Again, my grandaddy helped the Royal Flying Doctor Service greatly and was a great admirer of Dr Flynn. Every day that goes by the economic rationalists are removing that mantle of safety.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —After a discussion about one vote, one value, and native title and fringe benefits tax, we might profit from some discussion of the Civil Aviation Amendment Bill, which is before the House. That bill provides for the expansion of the board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority by adding two non‐executive members and empowering the minister to appoint a member as deputy chairperson.

SPEECH.PARA: As the opposition spokesman, the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) indicated, he is not opposing the bill, but he has moved an amendment arising from our concerns about the nature of those who should be on the board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. We would again invite the minister, as we have done before, to give an undertaking that he will not appoint anyone who is an active political lobbyist on behalf of one section of the aviation community.

We make the point that aviation has numerous factions and interests which are often in intense disagreement on major industrial issues, including safety regulation. If the board is to be a battleground for competing interests within the industry, I believe that the consequences for the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and aviation safety could be disastrous.

We have noted that the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association has been waging a bitter battle against the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, and that its position has essentially been partisan in relation to all this. We have some concerns about that position being given undue authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are the people involved. They are the people whose lives are at risk!
—They are not the only people whose lives are at risk, as I will go on to describe—
—Order! The member for Kennedy was heard in silence. He will do the House and the other speaker the courtesy of doing the same.

—I want to consider the issues of civil aviation safety firstly from the point of view of the recent inquiry into civil aviation safety, Plane safe , produced by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure as recently as December of last year. That was an inquiry into aviation safety in the commuter and general aviation sectors. Then I want to look at this subject from the point of view of a member of parliament responsible for the safety of constituents adjacent to an airport, the Essendon airport.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at the inquiry into aviation safety, we can see that the report has discussed the concept of affordable safety. The committee has expressed some concerns about that concept which I would endorse. My own view is that it is a very dangerous concept because it is a euphemism for market forces and deregulation which, in an area of safety standards, simply will not work. The committee at paragraph 2.50 suggested that the concept of affordable safety which was popularised by Dick Smith had within it the concept of accountability to the aviation industry and that that approach could indeed be an explanation for some of the shortcomings of the then Civil Aviation Authority in the performance of its duties.

It went on further to say that the Civil Aviation Authority was never captured by the aviation industry; on the contrary, the regulator offered itself as a willing captive. It went on to note submissions it had received that safety standards may well have been reduced. Arising out of this concept of affordable safety, you had Alan Terrell giving the opinion that safety standards had been reduced as a result of deregulation, devolution and delegation to industry commercialisation. He expressed the view that the safety position in general aviation may already be below an acceptable level if the insurance statistics showing a 40 per cent increase in general aviation claims between the early 1990s and the late 1980s could be translated into operational events.

You had the submission from the Australian Licensed Aircraft Engineers Association indicating that, in their view, safety standards had fallen disastrously. The committee went on to disregard the evidence given by Dick Smith because they pointed out that he had included balloon fatalities and excluded crew fatalities, which seemed quite extraordinary. They went on to conclude that there was some hard evidence of a decline in safety in the area of charter operations, although they said there was no hard evidence to show a deterioration of safety in other sectors of general aviation.

They also made some points about the possibility of competition within the industry leading to lower safety standards. In chapter 5 they referred to destructive competition. The Industry Commission noted that greater competition might provide an incentive for some operators not to fully comply with safety requirements and that there may be a case for strengthening enforcement procedures. The committee concluded that some preconditions existed for avoiding essential maintenance which endangered safety. They proposed a couple of steps to try and address what they described as destructive competition: the publication of serious deficiency reports and special surveillance of charter operators concerning their business background, aircrew skills and aircraft conditions.

BREAK.PARA: Chapter 7 of this inquiry into aviation safety dealt with the issue of bogus parts. A senior airworthiness inspector with the Civil Aviation Authority indicated to the committee that the use of bogus parts was entrenched and a well‐known feature of the industry, and that the Bureau of Air Safety Investigations had data that in the last 10 years there had been three cases where bogus parts were clearly a factor in aviation incidents. There was some concern expressed within the committee on the issue of bogus parts. The committee also expressed a view about emergency locater transmitters and said that those transmitters might be phased in. Since charter operators carry more people than other areas of general aviation, the committee therefore said that emergency locater transmitters perhaps could be installed in these aircraft first because the benefits of installing them were likely to be larger.

We have that background of concern about aviation safety being expressed by the House of Representatives standing committee. It is also the case for people in the electorate that I represent, the electorate of Wills, that there is considerable concern about the aviation safety standards applying at Essendon Airport. Most recently, we have had a report released on the December 1993 crash of a 1948 Dove aircraft, from the Essendon Airport, into five houses in Gilbertson Street, Essendon. My concern is that this long‐awaited report has failed to pursue recommendations which would guarantee that such a crash would not recur.

The report identifies the failure of the Dove's right engine, caused by failure of that engine's fuel control unit pumps, as the key cause of the crash. But its interim recommendation that all such fuel control unit pumps be inspected was rejected by the Civil Aviation Authority. The bureau meekly accepted this.

I would say that the Civil Aviation Authority's justifications for rejecting that recommendation were simply not good enough. They said, in the first place, that the cause of the fuel pump failure had not been adequately determined. That, in my view, is all the more reason for checking pumps in other planes.

Their second justification for not implementing this recommendation was the `operational and financial burden on Australian DH‐104 operators'. In my view, that surely must not be allowed to override the safety of aircraft travellers and those who live near airports. It is an expression of that concept of `affordable safety' which I referred to earlier and which I think is absolutely unacceptable.

The other thing the report does is identify the failure of the landing gear to retract when the pilot first selected it as a key reason that the plane was unable to fly with its remaining engine. It was a twin‐engine plane, so one engine failed and it was not able to fly with the other engine because the landing gear did not retract first time around. The report went on to state:
periodic checking of the adjustment of the landing gear selection system is therefore a critical practice that was not addressed in the systems of scheduled maintenance.

Yet the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation made no recommendation for landing gear maintenance to include this check. You would expect that a crash of this seriousness would at least lead to changes designed to prevent a recurrence. But, instead of receiving recommendations to address these problems, residents living around Essendon Airport are told that they are going to have to live with a lower safety standard than applies at, for example, Tullamarine. The report states:
if light aircraft are to be operated in a realistic manner, a level of safety lower than that present in large aircraft must be tolerated.
It also says:
During takeoff there is an accepted risk period within which, should an engine failure occur, an accident might result.

That period is up to 25 seconds. If that is the case, clearly the area of Essendon, which is completely surrounded by housing, is hardly the place for these risks. My view is that the situation is particularly serious concerning charter aircraft, because, as the report indicates:
No guarantees are provided regarding their ability to fly with one engine inoperative. The Certificate of Airworthiness simply doesn't require it.
If that is to continue to be the case, we should certainly not have charter flights operating out of Essendon.

On that count I, and the electorate that I represent, express considerable concern about safety standards. I express some concern because the minister—who, as a shadow minister, had a lot to say about aviation safety, much of which was of interest to me, representing the electorate that I do—has a mandate to improve safety standards, not a mandate to allow safety standards to slip.

I would raise some concern at the decision that the minister took, going back a couple of weeks, to override the Civil Aviation Safety Authority on the emergency locater transmitter issue. This was only a first issue and a first step, I guess. Nevertheless, it is not a happy precedent that the minister has chosen to ignore the view of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and to impose his own position on that issue. I express some concern about that.

I note that the minister made a lot out of safety issues when he was in opposition, with the Monarch crash and so on. These are important issues, and I used to share some of his concerns, because it was certainly my view that the Federal Airports Corporation and the management at Essendon Airport had always had a `she'll be right, mate' attitude and were forever playing down issues of aviation safety, and that they were not up‐front with me. I remember that, when the de Havilland Dove crashed in December 1993, I and everyone else who visited the site on that night thought, `That's it, then. The airport will surely close now; but look at the terrible cost in terms of the damage that it has done.'

I and others were amazed when the aviation authorities commenced glossing over this incident. And this is still happening. We had the owner‐operator and pilot of that plane, Mr Rudge, writing to a local paper and saying that the inquiry showed that he was not to blame. I just wonder what he thinks happened: that the plane fell out of the sky by itself? We had a school of criminologists in the 1970s who used to say that society was to blame. So you may wonder whether Mr Rudge thinks that society is to blame for the crash.

Even as recently as Saturday 15 June, just a week and a bit ago, we had eyewitness accounts of another near miss at Essendon Airport. Once again, the aviation authority was saying, `Oh, this wasn't too bad.' The spokeswoman for Airservices Australia was reported as saying that a Beechcraft Skipper was flying south on its final approach to runway 17 when a Piper Cherokee approached from the east. The Cherokee pilot had been instructed by the control tower to follow the Skipper. She said:
There was a student pilot in the Cherokee who turned on to the base leg without allowing enough distance to follow the Skipper.
The Skipper then had to make a go‐around and he would have pulled out of the situation to allow the aircraft that was supposed to let him in to land first.

According to eye witnesses, it was quite a serious incident, which occurred directly above de Havilland Avenue in Strathmore. It is most unsatisfactory from the point of view of local residents to have the procession of accidents and incidents that we have had at Essendon Airport and to have, once again, this being fobbed off by aviation authorities. We even have the situation where there is a fresh proposal for pilot training at Essendon Airport, with a proposal to establish a pilot training scheme for overseas pilots. Yet the near miss which occurred just a week and a half ago arose in relation to a trainee pilot, and it certainly heightens the case against the pilot school being established there.

In conclusion, the mandate of the transport minister is to improve air safety in this country. It will not happen by kowtowing to the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association. It will not happen by going with the concept of affordable safety, which is a pseudonym for market forces and the absence of the necessary regulation of safety standards. It will not happen by appointing, for example, Dick Smith to the board. These sorts of things would greatly concern both the opposition and people in my electorate.
Debate (on motion by Mr Neville) adjourned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mr Latham

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 9 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On what occasions since 1972 has the New South Wales Government requested the Commonwealth to contribute to the construction of new rail lines in Sydney's Greater West region.
(2) In each instance referred to in part (1), what projects were involved.
(3) Will the Government contribute funding to each outstanding project if requested to do so by the New South Wales Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) It is not possible to specify all occasions since 1972 when the NSW Government may have requested, either in writing or in discussions between Government Ministers or officials, Federal Government assistance to fund the construction of new rail lines in Sydney's Greater West region.

However, the Commonwealth has contributed funds to a number of projects which have enhanced rail infrastructure in the region, not only in response to requests from the NSW State Government but also as a direct result of Commonwealth program initiatives, which may have sought a prior indication from NSW of strategic priorities.

Specific instances since 1972, of track improvements or installation in the Greater Western Sydney area, which have been assisted by Commonwealth funds include the electrification of the Richmond to Riverstone line; construction of the line linking the Parramatta and Liverpool lines, known as the `Parramatta Y'; construction of the Macarthur turnback and loop; and construction of the Ingleburn/Glenfield crossing loop.

(3) The only active NSW State Government request for funding is for the acquisition of land for a rail corridor which would provide for the future development of a rail link to Sydney West Airport. The previous Government offered New South Wales $17 million for this purpose, subject to certain conditions. With the Federal Government's recent decision to broaden the Environmental Impact Statement(EIS) process, further consideration of this issue is dependent upon the outcome of the EIS.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Nursing Home and Hostel Licence: Selection Criteria

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Anthony, Larry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 9 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What (a) guidelines and (b) criteria does the Government use to determine the allocation of licences for nursing homes and hostel beds.
(2) Is the process referred to in part (1) based on regions; if so, how are the regions determined.
(3) Are demographic variations within specific regions a factor in the process.
(4) Are regions with a very high proportion of elderly persons allocated a greater proportion of the total number of licences granted nationally.
(5) When will the next round of licence allocations in the Far North Coast of New South Wales be completed.
(6) How many licences will be granted in the process referred to in part (5).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moylan, Judi, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The allocation of new nursing home and hostel places and community aged care packages in particular geographical areas is based on target planning ratios. These ratios are 40 nursing home places, 50 hostel places and 10 community aged care packages per thousand of population aged 70 and over. Within this framework, Aged Care Advisory Committees advise the Minister on regional allocations, taking into account factors like the existing provision of places, the target provision of places in relation to the ratios, the pressure on existing facilities, and the presence of other types of care.

(2) The process is based on regions, and within regions the needs of Statistical Local Areas are considered. In New South Wales the regions are the Commonwealth Department of Health and Family Services planning regions, which are determined to reflect broad communities of interest and are, as far as possible, consistent with our major funding partners, for example State health and community services departments.
(3) Yes.
(4) Yes. The allocation of new places is dependent upon both the number of older persons and existing service provision.
(5) Successful applicants can expect to be notified in the second half of the financial year.
(6) The regional allocation of new places for 1996‐97 has not yet occurred.
